'Honestly, <b>if you were any slower, you'd be going backward</b>.U+201D <br><br>U+201CHang on . . .U+201D Harry muttered to Ron. U+201CThereU+2019s an empty chair at the staff table. . . . </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer72482072" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3715824162499385887">The Harry Potter books are all well worth reading. I read this "back" when it came out (my kids grew up "as the books came out" and were adults by the time the series finished). The books do develop as they go along and slowly become somewhat darker volume by volume. There is more foreshadowing here more clues and a good solid story. Adults and children alike will like it. Just be sure with each volume that the child/youth in question is mature enough. Here the story is only 2 volumes along and</span>  <span id="freeText3715824162499385887" style="display:none">The Harry Potter books are all well worth reading. I read this "back" when it came out (my kids grew up "as the books came out" and were adults by the time the series finished). The books do develop as they go along and slowly become somewhat darker volume by volume. There is more foreshadowing here more clues and a good solid story. Adults and children alike will like it. Just be sure with each volume that the child/youth in question is mature enough. Here the story is only 2 volumes along and still not so dark as it will get.<br /><br />These books are exceptionally well written and as you delve into each book you get to know the characters better and better. Ms. Rowling does an incredible job in constructing not only her world but its inhabitants. But then they not only sold multiple millions of copies but seem to have inspired dozens (if not hundreds) of y/a books (and not a few adult adult reading level books)about (young) wizards and wizarding schools. Seems like Harry Potter may have been noticed. <br /><br />In this one we're going to find out more about the history of Hogworts and of course get clues and information that will serve us well as the series goes on. As the students of Hogworts come under threat stories of the long rumored Chamber of Secrets begin to circulate...is it real, has it been opened, was it ever opened before. <br /><br />Will anyone die?<br /><br />These are excellent books. </span>  <a data-text-id="3715824162499385887" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1273926897" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17100455029047154652">Warning, this review has spoilers for this book and the entire series.<br /><br />Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the second in the amazing Harry Potter series but it is not one of my favourites in the series. This book is still a kids book and feels innocent with it being more morally black and white than subsequent novels. Plus I never get how wizards can manage normal life without learning basic stuff like maths and science. <br /><br />In this book, during the conversation between Harry and Dumbledore, i</span>  <span id="freeText17100455029047154652" style="display:none">Warning, this review has spoilers for this book and the entire series.<br /><br />Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the second in the amazing Harry Potter series but it is not one of my favourites in the series. This book is still a kids book and feels innocent with it being more morally black and white than subsequent novels. Plus I never get how wizards can manage normal life without learning basic stuff like maths and science. <br /><br />In this book, during the conversation between Harry and Dumbledore, it has a massive spoiler about the ending of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hollows, particularly if you have read the Half-Blood Prince. This and all the books in this series have so many layers where at first it seems a simple story but also a story of good vs evil and the strength of love. <br /><br />The trio of friends has not really changed since the first book, but Harry is a bit snappier as he has got people believing he is attacking students. I like how Hogwarts feels like another character and changes in each book. I also like Dobby as he is loveable and Lockhart who makes me smile especially with the valentines Dwarves. <br /><br />Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is an amazing book full of mystery and danger and I would recommend it to fans of the first book. <br /><br />This and my other reviews can be found at <a href="http://amethystbookwyrm.blogspot.co.uk/" rel="nofollow">Amethyst Bookwyrm</a><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="17100455029047154652" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter id="freeTextContainer9140598197646736335">Originally read: 2001(I think)<br />Re-read-Most recent Sept 2016<br /><br /> Like all Harry Potter Books, I have read this several times. The first time was nearly 15 years ago. <br /><br />I like how we get a further look into other characters better. Hagrid, Dumbledore and Draco especially. Plus we get to meet the villainous Lucius Malfoy (Draco's father) and Ron's little sister Ginny (I have mixed thoughts on her in this book). The the</span>  <span id="freeText9140598197646736335" style="display:none">Originally read: 2001(I think)<br />Re-read-Most recent Sept 2016<br /><br /> Like all Harry Potter Books, I have read this several times. The first time was nearly 15 years ago. <br /><br />I like how we get a further look into other characters better. Hagrid, Dumbledore and Draco especially. Plus we get to meet the villainous Lucius Malfoy (Draco's father) and Ron's little sister Ginny (I have mixed thoughts on her in this book). Not to mention the house-elf Dobby, who is one interesting character and very unique. The the supremely annoying Gilderoy Lockhart (ugh, I despise him!).<br /><br />Something is attacking Harry's classmates and he is determined to figure out what and who is causing harm to the school. Harry's youth is obvious in this book. He seems to be a bit more foolish than even the first book. Gryffindor courage, eh? I think I noticed this more in the latest re-read than past times. The small oopses these kids make. Yet it is also what endears the book to me. The imperfection.<br /><br />We get more of a view of Diagon Alley, plus it's less savory companion, Knockturn Alley. I don't think I can ever learn enough about these places. So many interesting things and places! <br /><br />We get flying cars, giant spiders, an enchanted diary and pesky pixies, plus so much more in this second installment to the Harry Potter world</span> It's obvious to anyone who knows me how much I love these books, and for anyone who doesn't I'm not sure that I can add any more praise than these books have already received (and, rightfully so, in my opinion). The books are full of heart, wit, mystery and fantasy, humor and sadness, each page bringing more plot or more characterization, and often times both.<br />And the books are just as delightful upon the second read!<br /><br />**SPOILERS BELOW** <br /><br />DON'T READ IF YOU HAVEN'T FINISHED THE SERIES<br /><br />The second book still has a sense of safety about it, and the wizarding world isn't quite and dangerous as will be encountered in later books.<br />Also, upon knowing the final books, COS does have lots of clues and I find it amazing how much J.K. Rowling had figured out so early on!<br />I completely love these books! And there is nothing quite like a journey to Hogwarts with Harry, Ron, Hermione and everyone else!<br /><br />***<br />Yay! Time to re-read! I've been very curious to re-read this - not only because it's HP, but also because there's supposed to be so many hints to the final book! <i>U+201DIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</i></blockquote> <p>The magic that is Harry Potter continues in this second instalment.</p> <p>In HarryU+2019s second year at Hogwarts we finally learn the secret of why Hagrid was expelled, and why the sorting hat thought Harry would excel in the Slytherin House. </p> <p>We also learn more about the founding members of Hogwarts, and the mystery that is Tom Riddle is revealed. </p> <p>And Dobby the house-elf becomes HarryU+2019s protector in some very dangerous but well-meant ways. </p> <p>I absolutely loved everything about this book. The imagination of J.K. Rowling continues to astound and enthral me. ItU+2019s so wonderful seeing Harry, Ron and Hermoine grow as friends and in their own capabilities, and I especially enjoy seeing Hermoine realise that some rules are meant to be broken. </p> <p>I must admit with the reread of this series, I love noticing clues and interesting facts I didnU+2019t really understand when I originally read this series. I look forward to many rereads of this wonderful series.</p></span>  <a data-text-id="6044926858527522549" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> id="reviewTextContainer1483504758" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5477541591288921648"><b>.5 / 5</b><br><blockquote> <b>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</b> </blockquote><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is amazing, obviously. There are a few annoyances here and there (Dobby and Lockhart) but overall this book leaves me wanting more. <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1451780072i/17604270._SX540_.jpg" width="420" height="280" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>Hogwarts is just. so. so. so mesmerising and magical. <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1451780072i/17604271._SY540_.jpg" width="320" height="460" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>Another thing that I enjoyed greatly is the fact that each chapter (in the American HP edition) starts with a small illustration. I didn't grow up reading the Harry Potter books so I</span>  <span id="freeText5477541591288921648" style="display:none">U+2B50 U+2B50 U+2B50 U+2B50<b>.5 / 5</b><br><blockquote>  <b>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</b></blockquote><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is amazing, obviously. There are a few annoyances here and there (Dobby and Lockhart) but overall this book leaves me wanting more. <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1451780072i/17604270._SX540_.jpg" width="420" height="280" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>Hogwarts is just. so. so. so mesmerising and magical. <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1451780072i/17604271._SY540_.jpg" width="320" height="460" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>Another thing that I enjoyed greatly is the fact that each chapter (in the American HP edition) starts with a small illustration. I didn't grow up reading the Harry Potter books so I am not very familiar with the American and British editions. The first time I read Harry Potter was in the summer of 2014, not a very long time ago, and I lent the books from the library. I was <i>overjoyed</i> when I received the American HP editions for my birthday. The covers are stunning! I couldn't be happier ^ ^<br>.<br><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1435537985?book_show_action=false">My Review of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a><br>.<br>.<br>.<br><i>  <u>1st read in August 2014</u></i><br>U+2B50 U+2B50 U+2B50 U+2B50 U+2B50<b>/5 (9.75/10)</b><br><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is even more imaginative than <i>Harry Potter and the PhilosopherU+2019s Stone</i>. It seems quite impossible to achieve, but it is so, believe me, I have read both. The Chamber of Secrets contains even more light-hearted humour and queer but high-spirited people. Not to forget more creatures, some that make me crawl, literally. Spiders, phoenixes, house-elves, you name them and they are there. <br><br>I love how the Chamber of Secrets is a bit more challenging than the first novel. ItU+2019s a step up. Solving the riddles - pun intended - were more complicated and complex. As the characters are growing the riddles increasing in difficulty as well. I love the fact that there is clear character development. For example, Hermione, needs to convince Ronny and Harry (aka the rule breakers) to break the rules. She evolves as time goes by, as do the other characters. This is very realistic in its portrayal of the way people in the "real" world evolve and change too. <br><br>The novelU+2019s story line is superb, it is truly impeccable. The way everything is introduced, explained, and done is executed perfectly. I am in <i>love</i>. I, hereby declare, that ANY novel written by J.K. Rowling is deemed worthy of praise. I trust her to write well. She has my sword, my axe, and my bow. Sonja, daughter of Suhaila, at your service *bows gracefully*.<br><u>I cannot and I <i>will</i> not stop reading the sequels to this novel. Like many of you, I can say that I grew up reading Harry Potter books. And now that I grow up and I look back at that time with the perspective of my adult age, I can say that these books transformed me. They opened me the door to the world of imagination, the love of reading and later the love of writing. Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is one of my favorite books of the saga, it presents Dobby, one of the most endearing characters for all Harry fans.<br />I recommend reading all Harry Potter books to all children, teenager and adults who haven't yet done it. It's a great and balanced story with an exquisitely natural and beautiful writing.<br /><br />Spanish version: <br />Harry Potter y la CU+00E1mara Secreta es el segundo volumen de la saga del famoso mago. This is definitely not my favourite of the series, owing to an unfortunate two week trip to France for which my mother made me pack only two books. This was one of them, Prisoner of Azkaban, the other. The latter didnU+2019t suffer from the multiple readings (sometimes multiple times in one day) as much as this one did. Still, itU+2019s been a long time, so it wasnU+2019t too annoying U+2014 and IU+2019d even contrived to forget the sequence of some of the events.<br /><br />Actually, IU+2019m enjoying the reread more than I really anticipated. ItU+2019s nice to come back to Harry Potter now the hypeU+2019s died down a bit; to read it not because itU+2019s a cultural monolith and people are saying I have to, but because I feel like it. Helps that I donU+2019t have anything to prove, too; once it caught on in school, there were years where I just had to be reading more literary stuff, just because high school.<br /><br />ItU+2019s nice to come to these books for the friendships between Ron, Harry and Hermione; for the funny moments with Lockhart; for Dobby; for that thrill when it comes to the idea of Knockturn AlleyU+2026 for the bravery and heroism of Harry, who isnU+2019t particularly strong or smart (Hermione is a better witch than Harry a wizard, itU+2019s very clear), who has been thrown into the path of great events, and does what he can.<br /><br /><a href="http://breathesbooks.com/2015/04/13/review-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets/" rel="nofollow">Also posted here.</a></span>  <a Let's just go ahead and add that to the list of foreshadowing in my last review, shall we? <br /><br />15/12/2012<br />I first read Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets on a plane from London to Singapore in 1998. My mum handed it and Philosopher's Stone to me as I was boarding the plane, and told me to read them and let me know what she thought when she got back to Australia the following week. I read both books straight through without stopping. I read through dinner, and I kept reading when they dimmed the lights so everyone could go to sleep. <br /><br />Fourteen years later, I still love it. I love Gilderoy Lockhart's special bucket of crazy narcissism. I love the Ford Anglia. I love how there are so many little flashes of foreshadowing - the introduction of Azkaban, of Tom Riddle's diary, of the sword of Gryffindor, of the basilisk fangs, of Polyjuice potion. <br /><br To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(&#39;reviewTextContainer760267223&#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer760267223" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17935538452314559859">I finished this at 6 am today. Couldn't sleep so I grabbed it and just kept on reading until the end because I couldn't stop, even though I already knew the story. This was the one that truly made me fall in love with the series, the first one I read when I was a kid, and the one that I would reenact the most with my friends. This is bound to make every kid or grown up's imagination go wild: a flying car, a domestic elf named Dobby, a tree that hits back, plants that scream like little babies,</span>  <span id="freeText17935538452314559859" style="display:none">I finished this at 6 am today. Couldn't sleep so I grabbed it and just kept on reading until the end because I couldn't stop, even though I already knew the story. This was the one that truly made me fall in love with the series, the first one I read when I was a kid, and the one that I would reenact the most with my friends. This is bound to make every kid or grown up's imagination go wild: a flying car, a domestic elf named Dobby, a tree that hits back, plants that scream like little babies, the Polyjuice potion, the giant spiders, Fawkes, the basilisk ... I love it so much. I remember gasping in awe when I saw the movie scene where Tom Riddle reveals he's Voldemort even though I'd already read the book and now I found myself gasping quite a few times again. 5 stars</span>  <a data-text-id="17935538452314559859" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> id="reviewTextContainer1107824776" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer136281138331307898"><a href="http://aworldbetweenfoldedpages.blogspot.co.at/2014/12/review-harry-potter-and-chamber-of.html" rel="nofollow"> <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1425398542i/13884056.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>I'm still so intrigued by those amazing book covers! I absolutely adore them and if I'm being completely honest they were the reason why I started reading it but the more and more I dive into that magical world of Hogwarts I wanna go there myself, haha. How absolutely fantastic would that be?<br><br>I have to say that I didn't enjoy this book as much as the first one. I don't know why but maybe because not much happened? No, that's not really right. I just had a different feeling but that doesn't mean</span>  <span id="freeText136281138331307898" style="display:none"><a href="http://aworldbetweenfoldedpages.blogspot.co.at/2014/12/review-harry-potter-and-chamber-of.html" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1425398542i/13884056.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>I'm still so intrigued by those amazing book covers! I absolutely adore them and if I'm being completely honest they were the reason why I started reading it but the more and more I dive into that magical world of Hogwarts I wanna go there myself, haha. How absolutely fantastic would that be?<br><br>I have to say that I didn't enjoy this book as much as the first one. I don't know why but maybe because not much happened? No, that's not really right. I just had a different feeling but that doesn't mean I disliked it or so. Quite the opposite!<br><br><b>  <i>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities."</i></b><br><br>What (or more specific: Who) I probably liked most in book 2 is Ron Weasley. Seriously, he owns my heart. I love this clumsy and kind of awkward but still super cute boy. I was always looking forward to his scenes and no matter how tiny or "useless" they were, I enjoyed them all! He and his broken wand made me laugh so hard at times because those scenes were hilarious! And oh my, how protective he is over Hermione is just amazing. Yes, I already ship them.<br><br>Another favorite part of mine was Dobby! I'm in love with this little elf and I was so, so happy in the end! He definitely deserved it and gosh, I hope I'll meet him again soon!<br><br><b>  <i>"When in doubt, go to the library."</i></b><br><br>Professor Lockhart really annoyed me but I didn't expect anything else. He was weird in the movie too and therefore I knew it wouldn't be any different in the book. I think I even disliked him more in the book than in the movie (of course). The other Professors were all fantastic and I liked how everyone seemed to be annoyed by Mr. Perfect-Hair. The Duelling Club was also pretty awesome and I loved Snape for what he did to Lockhart! In general it's one of my favorite scenes in the whole book but also in the movie. It's great!<br><br>I was told it only gets better from now on and even though I've seen the movies - well, not all - I don't remember them anymore. Not 100% at least. I'm super curious and already can't wait to start book 3!<br><br><a href="http://aworldbetweenfoldedpages.blogspot.com" rel="nofollow">www.aworldbetweenfoldedpages.blogspot.com</a></span>  <a </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer851206878" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7825611850516925304"><strong>5 stars</strong><br />I haven't read <em>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</em> in over ten years, which is kind of a crazy thing to say. In fact, I've never read the books more than once (until now). I was talking with a coworker the other day about how reading a book when you're a [young] adult versus a child is a vastly different experience. You pick up on more, you have this air of nostalgia... Really, you just plain love it more. <br /><br />I don't think that's ever been more true for me than with Harry Potter. When I</span>  <span id="freeText7825611850516925304" style="display:none"><strong>5 stars</strong><br />I haven't read <em>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</em> in over ten years, which is kind of a crazy thing to say. In fact, I've never read the books more than once (until now). I was talking with a coworker the other day about how reading a book when you're a [young] adult versus a child is a vastly different experience. You pick up on more, you have this air of nostalgia... Really, you just plain love it more. <br /><br />I don't think that's ever been more true for me than with Harry Potter. When I read these books as a kid I loved them and thought they were fantastic, but I loved them the way a kid loves books. I'm so glad I got to grow up with them, but I don't think I appreciated them the same. <br /><br />Now, over ten years later, I can definitely say I appreciate these books a whole lot more. I love the characters, the storylines, the way it's written for children but reads like it's meant for absolutely anyone that wants to pick it up. It truly is timeless (I won't be surprised if Harry Potter is a classic in 50 years (maybe less)). <br /><br />The adventures of Harry, Ron, and Hermione will never be any less fun, and I know I'll miss the lighthearted air of the first two books once I dive in to the later part of the series. But still U+2014 I think the nostalgia that comes with reading these books over again will always be my favorite part, even if I'm going to be sobbing in <em>Deathly Hallows</em>. </span>  <a data-text-id="7825611850516925304" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1628371250" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer367726545932599628">This was my first time rereading this so I decided to listen to it on audiobook with Stephen Fry's narration and it was brilliant. He does such a great job at embodying all the characters and he's got a great sense of timing when it comes to putting emphasis on certain parts and what not.<br />I also thoroughly enjoyed picking up on all the small details and the foreshadowing, for not just the events at the end of the book but also in the following books. I haven't read the series since I was 11 so th</span>  <span id="freeText367726545932599628" style="display:none">This was my first time rereading this so I decided to listen to it on audiobook with Stephen Fry's narration and it was brilliant. He does such a great job at embodying all the characters and he's got a great sense of timing when it comes to putting emphasis on certain parts and what not.<br />I also thoroughly enjoyed picking up on all the small details and the foreshadowing, for not just the events at the end of the book but also in the following books. I haven't read the series since I was 11 so the film adaptations's storyline was what I had in my head so it almost felt like I was reading the book for the first time which made it that much more fun. <br />However, with that being said I also found myself picking up on a lot of small flaws or things that didn't quite add up for me but that didn't detract from my overall experience so this was easily a 5/5 read for me. I'm really excited to continue rereading the rest of the series. </span>  <a data-text-id="367726545932599628" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6546260-jeffrey-michael?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer286054140" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1751028279920943684">OK, so I suffer from prereadaphobia. That's the fear of reading a book before seeing the movie for fear that the movie won't measure up to the book. Well I LOVE the Harry Potter movies so I waited until after I had seen the last movie before starting on the first book. Well my fears weren't well founded in this case. I love the book as much as the movie. Well written and well paced, the movie accurately represented the novel which isn't all that common, take The Hunger Games for instance. I</span>  <span id="freeText1751028279920943684" style="display:none">OK, so I suffer from prereadaphobia. That's the fear of reading a book before seeing the movie for fear that the movie won't measure up to the book. Well I LOVE the Harry Potter movies so I waited until after I had seen the last movie before starting on the first book. Well my fears weren't well founded in this case. I love the book as much as the movie. Well written and well paced, the movie accurately represented the novel which isn't all that common, take The Hunger Games for instance. I understand that the book will have more details than the movie did but overall I'm pleased with both media types. Harry is progressing at Hogwarts and all the intrigue continues in his second year of his wizardry school. He-who-must-not-be-named continues to hover around the edges and flavors the entire story. If you've seen the movies and enjoyed them I highly recommend reading the books.</span>  <a data-text-id="1751028279920943684" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> The Weasly family is the best!<br /><br />Eh, now that everyone is at Hogwarts, not much is happening. This is slightly boring.<br /><br />Lockhart is the stupidest character.<br /><br />This Chamber of Secrets sounds pretty intense!<br /><br />Hey, Hermione is not quite as annoying as she was in the last book.<br /><br />Woah, this chamber thing really is intense!<br /><br />*last pages* <br />That was incredible!           >            <span id="freeTextContainer1361229370972102967">While I adore <b>everything</b> Harry Potter I will say this is one of my lesser favorites. But to me that's like saying I don't love pizza as much as I love hot wings. Because I fucking <i>love</i> pizza but hot wings are my everything...<i>I'd die for hot wings</i>.        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer57105742" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1593727351423206397">To be honest, this is not my favourite book in the Harry Potter series. I usually skip to book 3 during re-reads. <br />But, it not being my favourite doesn't make it a bad book. It's still entertaining, full of delightful characters, situations that go from serious to absurd. <br />With the Chamber of Secret's open, Harry has to face Voldermort again. You get just a little closer to learning more about what's going on with Harry. This is around the time Harry starts to realize the magical world isn't as ha</span>  <span id="freeText1593727351423206397" style="display:none">To be honest, this is not my favourite book in the Harry Potter series. I usually skip to book 3 during re-reads. <br />But, it not being my favourite doesn't make it a bad book. It's still entertaining, full of delightful characters, situations that go from serious to absurd. <br />With the Chamber of Secret's open, Harry has to face Voldermort again. You get just a little closer to learning more about what's going on with Harry. This is around the time Harry starts to realize the magical world isn't as happy as he thinks it is, what with how house elves are treated and all. He learns about the prejudices the magical world has for people of muggle decent and Squibs. <br />The seeds start to get planted for the later books. It just gets better from here.<br /><br />I recently re-read this. It's still not my favourite in the series, but you get to see how brave Harry is, as if we didn't know already. There's so many concepts that come to life in Book Six, which makes the series seem very well planned out. Little details that seem like you can just toss them aside play an important role.<br /><br /><br /><br />I still like this book, but the Mandrakes are morbidly funny. They're all like, we're going to stew these plant people up. Stuff like that makes me enjoy the crap out of her books. She just has a weird, and fun sense of humour that shows up in the series regardless of how dark things get. Harry Potter books are like delicious ice cream.</span>  <a data-text-id="1593727351423206397" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> The first time I read this book as I wasn't too thrilled with it and when I ordered my favorite Harry Potter books in order this one was number 6, however I feel like I like it much more ever since I have reread it as I've noticed that all these different things that I love about Harry Potter actually occurred in this installment like the flying car, meeting Dobby, having more Ginny and seeing more Hufflepuffs. I also forgot what a big part Professor Lockhart played in this book - I especially liked what he did for Valentines Day as this gave a chance for Ginny to show that she likes Harry quite a lot which is something we don't see in the movies till like the sixth movie I think. Overall I really did enjoy rereading this but I think I know now why I enjoyed it less than the others and it is probably because it feels like there isn't a lot of Hermione near the end because she gets petrified and if you didn't know she is one of my favorite characters out of the series. In about a months time or sooner I will probably pick up Prisoner of Azkaban as I am quite excited to be rereading that book - it is by far my favorite in the series!!</span>  <a id="reviewTextContainer47441558" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4477519129444621094">I'll be honest. When I found out that we were going to be re-reading this series, most of me was excited. But there was quite a bit of apprehension as well.<br /><br />Would I ruin the magic? Would I re-read these books with a much more critical eye and suddenly realize how poorly written they are? Does Harry Potter stand the test of time?<br /><br />I'm glad to say that if anythingU+2014and to my surprise and delightU+2014I enjoyed this book even more on a re-read. Picking it apart actually improves the book, as we marvel over</span>  <span id="freeText4477519129444621094" style="display:none">I'll be honest. When I found out that we were going to be re-reading this series, most of me was excited. But there was quite a bit of apprehension as well.<br /><br />Would I ruin the magic? Would I re-read these books with a much more critical eye and suddenly realize how poorly written they are? Does Harry Potter stand the test of time?<br /><br />I'm glad to say that if anythingU+2014and to my surprise and delightU+2014I enjoyed this book even more on a re-read. Picking it apart actually improves the book, as we marvel over the foreshadowing, or subtle hints, or hilarious phrases. <br /><br />Most of my detailed thoughts/analysis are in our <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/group/show/99675">book club's discussion threads</a>, which I invite you to visit and join in.<br /><br />Re-reading has been a lot of fun so farU+2014to pick things apart and acknowledge what a genius J.K. Rowling is, and also because this might be the tightest and most involved group read I've ever been a part of.<br /><br />It's only going to get better from here, as we leave the imaginative wonder of getting to know Hogwarts behind, and get into the headier and meatier topics and themes that Harry Potter explores.</span>  <a data-text-id="4477519129444621094" href="#" href="/user/show/5871712-tracy-cornerfolds">Tracy (Cornerfolds)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408855904" href="/book/show/22037377-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5871712-tracy-cornerfolds?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5871712-tracy-cornerfolds?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5871712-tracy-cornerfolds?shelf=read-2015">read-2015</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer196953904" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16579963995120522230"><a href="http://www.cornerfolds.com" rel="nofollow"> <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1424297765i/13742030.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>Book two picks up just as Harry is preparing to return to Hogwarts. His summer has been miserable with the Dursleys and he hasn't heard from his friends in months! Miserable and lonely, Harry meets a new character who I'd honestly forgotten was such a nuisance early on - Dobby the house elf. Thus begins the delightful second chapter of Harry Potter.<br><br>I. Love. These. Books. Honestly, I could end my review there, but I won't. Harry Potter is such a rare exception to my usual reading preference! I d</span>  <span id="freeText16579963995120522230" style="display:none"><a href="http://www.cornerfolds.com" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1424297765i/13742030.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>Book two picks up just as Harry is preparing to return to Hogwarts. His summer has been miserable with the Dursleys and he hasn't heard from his friends in months! Miserable and lonely, Harry meets a new character who I'd honestly forgotten was such a nuisance early on - Dobby the house elf. Thus begins the delightful second chapter of Harry Potter.<br><br>I. Love. These. Books. Honestly, I could end my review there, but I won't. Harry Potter is such a rare exception to my usual reading preference! I don't usually care for humor in books. You might think that makes me cold hearted, but I just really prefer other aspects of books more than jokes and silly situations. But what J.K. Rowling does with this series blends humor along with mystery, action, and adventure so seamlessly that I found myself laughing out loud on multiple occasions throughout the Chamber of Secrets and being totally charmed by it! Her writing is so unique and amazing!<br><br>Hermione is much more likable in book two, thank goodness. She is still a little goody two-shoes for my taste, but her redeeming qualities far outweigh the annoying ones. At least she breaks a few rules this time! Harry continues to learn more about himself and his connection to Voldemort, which is really interesting to read the second time around, knowing what will happen later on and being able to piece it all together. Ron continues to be a hilarious character who I always feel a little sorry for (hopefully he gets a new wand soon)!<br><br>Ginny, though... I know that she grows a lot through the series, but good grief she's dumb in this book. I can't help feeling that she acts much more immature than Harry, Ron, and Hermione did in their first year at Hogwarts, but maybe being the baby in the family will do that to a person. Professor Lockhart is so repulsive! I was right there with Ron and Harry gagging every time the man opened his mouth! Rowling definitely has a gift for bringing characters to life! As always, Dumbledore makes me smile and Draco makes me cringe... I could go on and on about all the other characters, but I'll stop there.<br><br>Reading this book again makes me wish (again) that I had read them as a child - before seeing the movies. Even though I had forgotten a lot of the details, I can't imagine what it would have been like experiencing the story for the first time by reading the books with no clue about what the Chamber of Secrets was! If, like me, you missed out on this one as a child, I highly recommend you give it a try now! You'll regret waiting so long.</span>  <a data-text-id="16579963995120522230" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review196953904">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link196953904" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=196953904&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_196953904'><a id="like_count_review_196953904" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/196953904?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_196953904" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_196953904" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=11&rating[page]=7&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=196953904&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_196953904" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 196953904, true, &#39;&#39;); (SOS BOOKS)" class="user" name="Erika B. (SOS BOOKS)" href="/user/show/4015201-erika-b-sos-books">Erika B. (SOS BOOKS)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4015201-erika-b-sos-books?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4015201-erika-b-sos-books?shelf=middle-reader">middle-reader</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4015201-erika-b-sos-books?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4015201-erika-b-sos-books?shelf=mind-blown">mind-blown</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer128764219" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9184966783347320653">Round two, book two! How could I have possibly forgotten how funny this book is?! Professor Gilderoy Lockhart is the man! I don't think I'll ever love a narcissistic character more than I do this "professor." He asks his students to write a poem about his achievements as homework. I love it! I shouldn't even start on my love for Dobby the house elf or you'll be reading this review for quite some time. I'd give that lovable little creature all of my socks. As I'm studying these and looking for</span>  <span id="freeText9184966783347320653" style="display:none">Round two, book two! How could I have possibly forgotten how funny this book is?! Professor Gilderoy Lockhart is the man! I don't think I'll ever love a narcissistic character more than I do this "professor." He asks his students to write a poem about his achievements as homework. I love it! I shouldn't even start on my love for Dobby the house elf or you'll be reading this review for quite some time. I'd give that lovable little creature all of my socks. As I'm studying these and looking for trauma and memory, I'm fascinated at what I'm finding. Memories so strong that they can come alive. Memories that can be obliterated in a moment with a spell. A cast system in the wizarding world made up of an ideology that there are wizards that are "pure" or "mudblood." The system going even darker/deeper by enslaving certain magical creatures. For the life of me, I can't figure out how Rowlings justified sending Harry back to the Dursley's when they had bars on his window and were feeding him through a pet door. Seems a bit harsh. #understatement Next up on my Potter revival-Azkaban!! :) <br /><br /><i> "Harry-I think I've just understood something! I've got to go to the library!" And she sprinted away, up the stairs. "What does she understand?" said Harry distractedly, still looking around, trying to tell where the voice had come from. "Loads more than I do," said Ron, shaking his head. "But why's she got to go to the library?" "Because that's what Hermione does," said Ron, shrugging. "When in doubt, go to the library." -pg 255 </i><br /><br /><i> It is our choices, Harry, that shows what we truly are, far more than our abilities." -pg 333 </i></span>  <a I also disliked Ginny intensely and didn't enjoy the way she was b</span>  <span id="freeText6453247662680722690" style="display:none">[First read: December 2001. 4 stars.<br />Second read: 28th January, 2016. 2 stars.]<br /><br />Read as part of the <a target="_blank" href="https://xleptodactylous.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/infinite-variety-book-challenge-2016.html" rel="nofollow">#InfiniteVariety2016 Reading Challenge</a> based on the BBC's Big Read poll.<br /><br />I can't say I was taken with this one. I think, from what I've seen, this is the least favourite book (and film) amongst the Potterheads and (up to now) I think I agree. There was a lot of to-ing and fro-ing in relation to the previous book and repetition galore. I also disliked Ginny intensely and didn't enjoy the way she was basically just a damsel to be used and rescued. I am also getting tired of how many times the female characters are being described as "being giggly" every time they get in a group of two or more.<br /><br />It's written fairly well, though I did notice a few typos. I think the series really takes off once the books get a bit longer but the earlier ones are basically just children's books with fun magic stuff. It was a rather tedious read (and that 2-and-a-half hour long film was dire) but I still don't hate Harry Potter or the world in general, so it's still going well.</span>  <a elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1056207423" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1056207423" />    <a title="Jonathan" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6313408-jonathan"><img alt="Jonathan" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478230200p2/6313408.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1056207423?book_show_action=false">Feb 24, 2015</a>      <a title="Jonathan" class="user" name="Jonathan" href="/user/show/6313408-jonathan">Jonathan</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=children-s-literature">children-s-literature</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=favourite-series">favourite-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=worldbuilding">worldbuilding</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1056207423" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5059613952948990900"><br />This is not how I believe a strong sequel should progress. When you do all the groundwork in the first novel, why cover the exact same territory yet again? The book adds little to the world-building and I am left questioning the limitations and ways in which the magic in Harry Potter's world actually works. What distinguishes 'good magic' from 'bad magic'? What stops anyone simply casting a spell? I know that the spells end up going wrong without practice but there really aren't a lot of procedu</span>  <span id="freeText5059613952948990900" style="display:none"><br />This is not how I believe a strong sequel should progress. When you do all the groundwork in the first novel, why cover the exact same territory yet again? The book adds little to the world-building and I am left questioning the limitations and ways in which the magic in Harry Potter's world actually works. What distinguishes 'good magic' from 'bad magic'? What stops anyone simply casting a spell? I know that the spells end up going wrong without practice but there really aren't a lot of procedures or ideas in these books that explain any of that to me.<br /><br />So my 'review' here will stand as a brief examination of how I've found the first two books in this series. Books that I finally decided to read after a long history of more classic children's novels and fantasy. The question at this point is: why did these books become so popular?<br /><br />Firstly is it the fantasy? I will say that most of the fantasy ideas in these two books are old-hat. Sure there are some new ideas or new ways of using the ideas here and there but on the whole the books are a conglomeration of previous myths, fairytales and folklore. So maybe these books made these ideas more accessible for a whole generation to see how interesting the whole fantasy genre was?<br /><br />Another thought that comes to mind is the whole 'growing up with Harry' method. By which I refer to how Harry Potter ages as his readers age, meaning that. Yet, that said, he lacks any great definition as a character. I'm sorry to anyone who said J.K. Rowling was a brilliant prose author - yes I see her moments from time to time but on the whole she spends her novel writing so sparsely and telling her readers so much about her characters that I just wish she would spend some time 'showing' now and then. <br /><br />Which leads me to one other point: marketing. Which is why I was so skeptical about these novels for so long. I looked at the craze surrounding them and thought: it seems like some fad of marketing. And reading these, trying to be critical, I would agree. The plotting is messy (which may be better in the films, but again I haven't seen those because I tend to read the books first), the characterization and development isn't great in the first two books and most of the ideas are sourced from elsewhere. So my conclusion stands that these books became so popular because they were a whole new line of 'popular fantasy' (and the movies helped too). It's the same thing I see happening with Game of Thrones and what I saw happen with Hunger Games and Divergent (though I like Hunger Games a little more).<br /><br />Anyway, that's enough from me. At least until I finish <i>A Dance with Dragons</i> and can complain about that instead. Although my complaining is happy complaining, if that makes any sense. The kind of complaining where I'm trying to let people know why I don't think it's as good as popularity demands...</span>  <a data-text-id="5059613952948990900" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; Anyway, the characters are so well-developed. They are unique in their own way. The golden trio(Harry,Hermione and Ron) are my absolute favourite of the characters. The plot is also amazing! There are twists everywhere which I couldn't have guessed. I am really amazed by this book and I adore it :D I must say J.K. Rowling's writing is really beautiful. I don't think any other witch book can be on par with the Harry Potter series. (I don't mean to offend anyone by this statement. It's just how I really feel XD)</span>  <a data-text-id="16503364393731077392" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1348642450" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1348642450" />    <a title="I SNIFF BOOKS - Beth" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30704264-i-sniff-books---beth"><img alt="I SNIFF BOOKS - Beth" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467608785p2/30704264.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1348642450?book_show_action=false">Jul 29, 2015</a>      <a title="I SNIFF BOOKS - Beth" class="user" name="I SNIFF BOOKS - Beth" href="/user/show/30704264-i-sniff-books---beth">I SNIFF BOOKS - Beth</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30704264-i-sniff-books---beth?shelf=middle-grade-chapter-books">middle-grade-chapter-books</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30704264-i-sniff-books---beth?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1348642450" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5778350758932401743">Even though IU+2019m a contributor to a comics media outlet, I have to sheepishly admit, I donU+2019t get all obsessive with details about comic book storylines U+2014 I reserve all that fervor for Harry Potter. This is my 4th reread of the series but thereU+2019s always some kind of new detail I notice every timeU+2026<br /><br />**If you have not read this book yet there are spoilers below.**<br /><blockquote><b>(1) How do Muggles send mail to Hogwarts?</b> Harry always chooses to remain at Hogwarts during vacation breaks. The DursleyU+2019s send Harry a path</blockquote></span>  <span id="freeText5778350758932401743" style="display:none">Even though IU+2019m a contributor to a comics media outlet, I have to sheepishly admit, I donU+2019t get all obsessive with details about comic book storylines U+2014 I reserve all that fervor for Harry Potter. This is my 4th reread of the series but thereU+2019s always some kind of new detail I notice every timeU+2026<br /><br />**If you have not read this book yet there are spoilers below.**<br /><blockquote><b>(1) How do Muggles send mail to Hogwarts?</b> Harry always chooses to remain at Hogwarts during vacation breaks. The DursleyU+2019s send Harry a pathetic Christmas present every year U+2014 how do they get their package to him? I certainly cannot imagine the DursleyU+2019s using owls. Likewise, Hermione left behind her copy of <i>Hogwarts: A History</i> at home because there was no room in her trunk U+2014 LockhartU+2019s books took up so much space! If the DursleyU+2019s can send Harry small parcels, why couldnU+2019t HermioneU+2019s Muggle parents have sent the book to her? (Plot-wise, I understand why this option wasnU+2019t explored, but it does make me wonder how Muggle families communicate with their kids at Hogwarts.)<br /><br /><b>(2) Some of the Hogwarts staff are OLD:</b> Hagrid was 13 when the Chamber of Secrets was opened. This book takes place 50 years later so Hagrid is 63. Likewise, Dumbledore is OLD too. Dumbledore was already on staff at Hogwarts (as the Tranfiguration teacher) when those events 50 years prior took place took place U+2014 he is much older than 63.<br /><br /><b>(3) Dobby, Draco Malfoy, and the Chamber of Secrets:</b> IU+2019m still not 100% sure what Dobby would have ever overheard about the Chamber of Secrets to cause him to try to prevent Harry from returning to Hogwarts. Dobby says that Harry will be in U+201Cmortal dangerU+201D (16) and that there is a plot U+201Cto make most terrible things happen at HogwartsU+201D (16). Dobby also says that he has known about the plot for months.<br /><br />Also, when Chamber of Secrets related messages were painted on the castle walls, Malfoy already seemed to be in the loop about them and also was not concerned for his own safety. Yes, the Chamber of Secrets is a legend, so perhaps Malfoy already had heard about it, but yet the students in the History of Magic class taught by Professor Binns were so keen to have him relate the story to them.<br /><br />But back to DobbyU+2026 What kind of conversation took place at the Malfoy Manor over the summer to have caused Dobby to try to prevent Harry Potter from returning to Hogwarts? I donU+2019t even understand why Dobby felt Harry was in mortal danger. House-elves have magic all of their own so maybe Dobby could read between the lines and figure some stuff out that I havenU+2019t even figured yet?<br /><br /><b>(4) Moaning Myrtle is a ghost:</b> Yes, we all know that. Even though I just finished reading <i>SorcererU+2019s Stone</i>, I canU+2019t recall if Moaning Myrtle was mentioned in the first book. Regardless, Moaning Myrtle is a GHOST. 50 years prior, the basilisk killed Myrtle. Myrtle says that she floated away but then came back and that she U+201Cwas determined to haunt Olive HornbyU+201D (page 299).<br /><br />I got the impression (perhaps from <i>Order of the Phoenix</i>) from Sir Nick, the ghost of Gryffindor House, that becoming a ghost after death takes advance planning. Myrtle died unexpectedly, not sure what year she was at Hogwarts, but letU+2019s assume too inexperienced to U+201Cdo the magicU+201D to let herself come back as a ghost. Is MyrtleU+2019s desire (perhaps even when she was still alive) to haunt Olive Hornby enough for Myrtle to have come back as ghost?<br /><br />Perhaps some witches and wizards do U+201Cplan aheadU+201D and become ghosts after their natural lives end. Perhaps for others who die before their time, becoming a ghost is random and spontaneous. Case in point, Professor Bins (History of Magic teacher) is said to have died in the teacherU+2019s lounge but simply rose up from his chair (as a ghost) and continued to go about teaching his classes. Also, Myrtle mentions to Harry that if he had died in the Chamber of Secrets, she would have shared her toilet with him (326). Perhaps Myrtle was just hoping this random becoming-a-ghost thing would happen with Harry if he had died.<br /><br />(As a side note, it is interesting to note that it seems that Myrtle did not tell anyone that Hermione, Harry, and Ron were brewing polyjuice potion in her bathroom. Myrtle seems quite lonely so perhaps she enjoyed their presence even though a lot of times the three of them just ignored her.)<br /><br /><b>(5) Awards:</b> After the Chamber of Secrets ordeal, in McGonagallU+2019s office, Dumbledore says that Ron and Harry will both receive Special Awards for Services to the School (331). In all seven books, there is never any description of any kind of awards ceremony. Perhaps Dumbledore merely makes these award announcements in the Great Hall at meal times U+2014 or maybe a proper awards ceremony is held each year but Rowling chooses not incorporate it into the stories. (And letU+2019s not forget, that during one detention supervised by Filch, Ron had to polish the silver in the trophy room. (118))</blockquote><br />I have to say, I am VERY MUCH enjoying my re-read of the entire series and look forward to starting <i>Order of the Phoenix</i> later, but for me, <i>Chamber of Secrets</i> is not as excellent as <i>SorcererU+2019s Stone</i>, mainly because of my thoughts for item (3).<br /><br /><br />all my reviews can be found at <a target="_blank" href="http://www.isniffbooks.wordpress.com" rel="nofollow">www.isniffbooks.wordpress.com</a><br /><br />re-read from July 22, 2015 - July 29, 2015.</span>  <a data-text-id="5778350758932401743" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1595804283?book_show_action=false">Oct 25, 2016</a>      <a title="Sarah" class="user" name="Sarah" href="/user/show/3344685-sarah">Sarah</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780545791328" href="/book/show/29241319-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3344685-sarah?shelf=books-i-own-print">books-i-own-print</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3344685-sarah?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3344685-sarah?shelf=british-author">british-author</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3344685-sarah?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1595804283" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7201535905915114292">I absolutely adore these illustrated editions of the <b>Harry Potter</b> series, the first one was stunning and the <b>Chamber of Secrets</b> is just as beautiful so I can't wait to have the entire series on sitting on my shelves! I'm not going to talk about the story in this review (I've already done that <a href="http://www.feelingfictional.com/2013/12/review-harry-potter-and-chamber-of.html" rel="nofollow">HERE</a>) so instead I'll focus on the quality of the book and the artwork.<br><br>Just like the <b>Philosopher's Stone</b> illustrated edition this is a beautiful book in every way possible, I'm sure everyone who is looking</span>  <span id="freeText7201535905915114292" style="display:none">I absolutely adore these illustrated editions of the <b>Harry Potter</b> series, the first one was stunning and the <b>Chamber of Secrets</b> is just as beautiful so I can't wait to have the entire series on sitting on my shelves! I'm not going to talk about the story in this review (I've already done that <a href="http://www.feelingfictional.com/2013/12/review-harry-potter-and-chamber-of.html" rel="nofollow">HERE</a>) so instead I'll focus on the quality of the book and the artwork.<br><br>Just like the <b>Philosopher's Stone</b> illustrated edition this is a beautiful book in every way possible, I'm sure everyone who is looking at this already owns the previous one and has a good idea what to expect but just in case you're considering buying both illustrated versions I'll give you the highlights. These books are large hardbacks with good quality glossy pages full of wonderful illustrations to go along with the familiar text of the story. I love the way the illustrations vary from tiny little images through to whole double page spreads because you just never know what you'll find when you turn over the page. These books are an experience and they beg to be read out loud with children or to have someone sit for hours just studying the pictures.<br><br><b>Jim Kay</b> has really done such a fabulous job of bringing the stories to life in a different way, it would have been so easy to base these images on the movies that we're all so familiar with but he's created his own version of the world and the characters that are similar enough to be easily recognised but still completely his own versions.<br><br>I honestly could have included hundreds of pictures with this review but I've tried to narrow it down to just a few of my favourites.<br><br><a href="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-eBztr2LdA1k/WA8bCNVniAI/AAAAAAAAOpY/gN0tbUNGftU3uSTvAn1whHtmnh4EUp4rACLcB/s1600/HP+7.JPG" rel="nofollow">  <img stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/7985650?book_show_action=false">Oct 22, 2007</a>      <a title="Carmen Maloy" class="user" name="Carmen Maloy" href="/user/show/563625-carmen-maloy">Carmen Maloy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">everyone</span></div>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer7985650" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8360346978244543207">What stands out in book 2:<br /><br />* The de-gnoming of the Weasleys' garden. Harry discovers that even wizards have chores--gnomes must be grabbed (ignoring angry protests "Gerroff me! Gerroff me!"), swung about (to make them too dizzy to come back), and tossed out of the garden--this delightful scene highlights Rowling's clever and witty genius. <br />* Harry's first experience with a Howler, sent to Ron by his mother. <br />* The Dueling Club battle between Harry and Malfoy. Gilderoy Lockhart starts the Dueling Cl</span>  <span id="freeText8360346978244543207" style="display:none">What stands out in book 2:<br /><br />* The de-gnoming of the Weasleys' garden. Harry discovers that even wizards have chores--gnomes must be grabbed (ignoring angry protests "Gerroff me! Gerroff me!"), swung about (to make them too dizzy to come back), and tossed out of the garden--this delightful scene highlights Rowling's clever and witty genius. <br />* Harry's first experience with a Howler, sent to Ron by his mother. <br />* The Dueling Club battle between Harry and Malfoy. Gilderoy Lockhart starts the Dueling Club to help students practice spells on each other, but he is not prepared for the intensity of the animosity between Harry and Draco. Since they are still young, their minibattle is innocent enough, including tickling and dancing charms. <br />* We learn more about Tom Riddle, aka Voldemort<br /><br /><br />Amazon Review<br />It's hard to fall in love with an earnest, appealing young hero like Harry Potter and then to watch helplessly as he steps into terrible danger! And in J.K. Rowling's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Book_2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Book 2) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a>, the much anticipated sequel to the award-winning <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Book_1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Book 1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a>, he is in terrible danger indeed. As if it's not bad enough that after a long summer with the horrid Dursleys he is thwarted in his attempts to hop the train to the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry to begin his second year. But when his only transportation option is a magical flying car, it is just his luck to crash into a valuable (but clearly vexed) Whomping Willow. Still, all this seems like a day in the park compared to what happens that fall within the haunted halls of Hogwarts. <br />Chilling, malevolent voices whisper from the walls only to Harry, and it seems certain that his classmate Draco Malfoy is out to get him. Soon it's not just Harry who is worried about survival, as dreadful things begin to happen at Hogwarts. The mysteriously gleaming, foot-high words on the wall proclaim, "The Chamber of Secrets Has Been Opened. Enemies of the Heir, Beware." But what exactly does it mean? Harry, Hermione, and Ron do everything that is wizardly possible--including risking their own lives--to solve this 50-year-old, seemingly deadly mystery. This deliciously suspenseful novel is every bit as gripping, imaginative, and creepy as the first; familiar student concerns--fierce rivalry, blush-inducing crushes, pedantic professors--seamlessly intertwine with the bizarre, horrific, fantastical, or just plain funny. Once again, Rowling writes with a combination of wit, whimsy, and a touch of the macabre that will leave readers young and old desperate for the next installment.<br /></span>  <a <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1324830020?book_show_action=false">Jul 29, 2016</a>      <a title="Carrie {The Butterfly Reader}" class="user" name="Carrie {The Butterfly Reader}" href="/user/show/30055062-carrie-the-butterfly-reader">Carrie {The Butterfly Reader}</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30055062-carrie-the-butterfly-reader?shelf=march-2016">march-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1324830020" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3725792916307391286">This novel picks up with Harry at home with those dreadful Dursleys. I'm still wishing I could jump inside this book and beat them within an inch of their life. But I'm getting off topic... it's just a few months after the first novel ended, summer vacation. On a very important night for Mr Dursley, Harry is confined to his room, where a mysterious house elf named Dobby. Dobby tells Harry that he can't come back to going Hogwarts as something bad would happen! Harry refuses as he can't stay here</span>  <span id="freeText3725792916307391286" style="display:none">This novel picks up with Harry at home with those dreadful Dursleys. I'm still wishing I could jump inside this book and beat them within an inch of their life. But I'm getting off topic... it's just a few months after the first novel ended, summer vacation. On a very important night for Mr Dursley, Harry is confined to his room, where a mysterious house elf named Dobby. Dobby tells Harry that he can't come back to going Hogwarts as something bad would happen! Harry refuses as he can't stay here any longer, so Dobby does something terrible trying to keep Harry from going.<br /><br />Harry is trapped, Mr Dursley has locked him in his room and barred his windows but it doesn't stop Harry with the help from the Weasley's he gets out of that horrid place. Before heading to Hogwarts they have to stop and gather the supplies for the year in Diagon Alley. Here they run into Mr Malfoy (whom I wish would die in a fire like yesterday) and Lockhart (who I also wish would go die in fire). It was really cool to see Mr Malfoy and Mr Weasley got into a scuffle which so should've been in the movie!<br /><br />After a whole lot of trouble getting to Hogwarts, Harry and Ron get into quite a bit of trouble but luckily they don't get expelled. So classes start up and guess who just happens to be their new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher? Lockhart! It's so easy to be annoyed by him like Harry and Ron are. Its's not hard to tell he's a fake from a mile away.<br /><br />Harry starts hearing a voice that no one else can hear. It's also revealed that he can talk to snakes. Which is a very Slytherin like trait, coming all the way from THE Slytherin. Then terrible things start to happen... Finch's cat gets petrified with an eerie message left on the wall It's not long after that even students are in danger including Hermione! Many believe it's Harry, opening the Chamber like this and hurting the students.<br /><br />After putting all the pieces together, Harry ends up down in the Chamber of Secrets, facing off against a huge snake and young Voldemort! It all ends well though, Harry saves the day as he does each book, though this time he also sets Dobby free!<br /><br />This one was so much better than the first one. I'm glad I read it. My partner says each book just keeps getting better and I hope he's right. I can't wait to find out if he's right!<br /><br />I do have one silly nit pick with this book, the end where Harry puts the diary into his sock.... could that work? I have small feet and no book, even a small one is going to fit in my sock... yeah that scene is my favorite from the movie but it just made me laugh so hard when I read it and I know that wasn't the right reaction to Dobby being saved.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="3725792916307391286" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="/user/show/2314568-steve"><img alt="Steve" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1463021489p2/2314568.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1246980460?book_show_action=false">Apr 08, 2015</a>      <a title="Steve" class="user" name="Steve" href="/user/show/2314568-steve">Steve</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439554893" href="/book/show/4.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2314568-steve?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2314568-steve?shelf=read-in-2015">read-in-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2314568-steve?shelf=rmfao-2015-genre-challenge">rmfao-2015-genre-challenge</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2314568-steve?shelf=ya">ya</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1246980460" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer221361847574523007">4.5 stars<br /><br />J.K. Rowling hit upon a tried and true formula, and she uses it to perfection.<br /><br />The second in the series about the young orphaned wizard, Harry Potter, starts off similarly to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a>. During the summer break between his first and second year at Hogwarts, Harry is again subjected to the brunt indignities by the Dursley family, his Muggle-born aunt and uncle, and their annoying son.<br /><br />As in the first novel, Harry is rescued from life in the mundane world and spen</span>  <span id="freeText221361847574523007" style="display:none">4.5 stars<br /><br />J.K. Rowling hit upon a tried and true formula, and she uses it to perfection.<br /><br />The second in the series about the young orphaned wizard, Harry Potter, starts off similarly to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a>. During the summer break between his first and second year at Hogwarts, Harry is again subjected to the brunt indignities by the Dursley family, his Muggle-born aunt and uncle, and their annoying son.<br /><br />As in the first novel, Harry is rescued from life in the mundane world and spends his second year at Hogwarts, tracking down the heir of Slytherin, who is turning an alarming number of Hogwarts' students to stone. If there is any one complaint I can make about this book in good conscience, it is that the book is far too similar to the first book in the series. There is very little deviation between the two. Don't let that put you off from reading this book. It is a very palatable book, exceptionally easy to read and "get into" and hard to put down! Rowling's style is a bit formulaic, but it's a formula that works!<br /><br />Once again, this book explores the differences between good and evil, further examining free will and free choice versus destiny. It's a great children's book that teaches children that they can choose to do the right thing even when they're being pigeonholed or pressured into doing the wrong thing.<br /><br />While I haven't read the books (or seen the movies) before, it seems to me that several items of interest were dropped in this book, or at least hinted at. For me, that remains to be seen. If I'm correct, Ms. Rowling is much more adept at crafting a long series and tying minuscule events and statements together than I expected.<br /><br />On to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a>!</span>  <a data-text-id="221361847574523007" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>
