id="reviewTextContainer1114795727" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer506934699608896490">Summary:<br />All Harry Potter wants is to get away from the Dursleys and go back to Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. But just as he's packing his bags, Harry receives a warning from a strange, impish creature named Dobby - who says that if Harry Potter returns to Hogwarts, disaster will strike.<br />And strike it does. For in Harry's second year at Hogwarts, fresh torments and horrors arise, including an outrageously stuck-up new professor, Gilderoy Lockheart, a spirit named Moaning Myrtle who</span>  <span id="freeText506934699608896490" style="display:none">Summary:<br />All Harry Potter wants is to get away from the Dursleys and go back to Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. But just as he's packing his bags, Harry receives a warning from a strange, impish creature named Dobby - who says that if Harry Potter returns to Hogwarts, disaster will strike.<br />And strike it does. For in Harry's second year at Hogwarts, fresh torments and horrors arise, including an outrageously stuck-up new professor, Gilderoy Lockheart, a spirit named Moaning Myrtle who haunts the girls' bathroom, and the unwanted attentions of Ron Weasley's younger sister, Ginny.<br />But each of these seem minor annoyances when the real trouble begins, and someone--or something--starts turning Hogwarts students to stone. Could it be Draco Malfoy, a more poisonous rival than ever? Could it possibly be Hagrid, whose mysterious past is finally told? Or could it be the one everyone at Hogwarts most suspects... Harry Potter himself. <br />Plot:<br />It's Harry Potter you guys! Of course the plot was genius! It held so much surprises, and brilliant world-building. I do have to say I especially liked the mandrakes. This being my Third time reading it, I can't say a lot of new things about it. <br />Writing:<br />Jk Rowling is my favorite writer of all time, and always will be. She is the best author I have ever read! Her writing is so complex, and wonderful. I could go on and on!<br />Characters:<br />There was definitely character development in this book. I especially like Hermione and her courage, even thought no one gives her the credit she deserved. Ron, on the other hand, comes off as a bit rood to me. I still love him, but he's not my favorite. <br />Overall:<br />On to rereading the prisoner of azkaban! Everything about this book was brilliant and amazing.<br />Recommendations:<br />Everyone needs to read this series!!!! I wish I could've written a longer review, but not as much stood out to me because it's my third time reading it. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="506934699608896490" href="#"         </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1624498530" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7707952845618432889">Twelve year old Harry Potter is once again living with the Dursleys for the summer before beginning a new school term. Things are not going well until Ron Weasley and his brothers come to his rescue and take Harry to their home. As Harry and his friends return to Hogwarts, they find some strange things are happening. Students have been attacked in the hallways and left petrified. Harry hears a whispering in the walls, but no one else seems to notice it. Harry, Ron and Hermione come to the</span>  <span id="freeText7707952845618432889" style="display:none">Twelve year old Harry Potter is once again living with the Dursleys for the summer before beginning a new school term. Things are not going well until Ron Weasley and his brothers come to his rescue and take Harry to their home. As Harry and his friends return to Hogwarts, they find some strange things are happening. Students have been attacked in the hallways and left petrified. Harry hears a whispering in the walls, but no one else seems to notice it. Harry, Ron and Hermione come to the conclusion that someone has opened the legendary Chamber of Secrets. They must find the opening and stop the monster that lives within.<br /><br />The second Harry Potter book is just as good as the first. This time around Harry and his friends ride in a flying car, meet an elf named Dobby and a ghost who inhabits a bathroom, and find a diary with invisible ink. New characters in the series include Ron's little sister, Ginny, and a new professor at Hogwarts, Gilderoy Lockhart. I listened to the audio version of this book. You can't beat Jim Dale's excellent narration. My rating: 5 Stars.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="7707952845618432889" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter  >            <span id="freeTextContainer18266331531011131061">5 "The Perfect Family Read" Stars! <br /><br />Wow, I am totally loving the Harry Potter adventure that I have been leisurely taking as a joint family read with my 10 year-old daughter and 8 year-old son! Witches, wizards, ghosts, giant spiders and secret chambers, this second installment of the Harry Potter series seems to have it all! I particularly enjoyed some of the glimpses of the past that were interwoven into this story which helped me better understand the influences behind the present struggles between good and evil in JK Rowling's creative magical world. And the humor! It was so interesting watching my children grasp and appreciate the satire behind Professor Lockheart's character. It definitely led to some interesting conversations!<br /><br />I can't wait to continue exploring Harry Potter's world in Book 3, the Prisoner of Azkaban, which is my next planned family read!<br Chamber of Secrets is such a great second instalment. Personally, I love all the setting up it does for the later books. <br /><br />This book the one that scares me the most. I genuinely get freaked out by the giant spiders and snakes and everything else. I also love Gilderoy Lockhart -- even though he's probably the worst teacher they've ever had, he makes me laugh. He's such a loser oh my god. <br /><br />I also love Draco in this one! Draco's eternal bitterness makes me laugh so much. <br /><br />The mystery of Chamber of Secrets is one of my favourites. I love how everything comes together o perfectly. Even petrified Hermione continues to keep everyone's shit together. <br /><br />Anyway, obviously a 5*.      <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1584668120" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4550780854042867259"><b>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets by J.K Rowling - 4.75/5 stars</b><br><br>This is the second year of Hogwarts that Harry's attending and prior to his arrival into the school, he is back at his Muggel family, the Dursley's. They're really horrible people! Harry misses his school and his friends and he is disheartened to find that neither Ron nor Hermoine have written to him. He feels as though what happened last year was nothing but just a dream; a dream he wishes to relive again. <br><br>Little did he know,</span>  <span id="freeText4550780854042867259" style="display:none"><b>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets by J.K Rowling - 4.75/5 stars</b><br><br>This is the second year of Hogwarts that Harry's attending and prior to his arrival into the school, he is back at his Muggel family, the Dursley's. They're really horrible people! Harry misses his school and his friends and he is disheartened to find that neither Ron nor Hermoine have written to him. He feels as though what happened last year was nothing but just a dream; a dream he wishes to relive again. <br><br>Little did he know, it was the work of an elf named Dobby who is here to warn him and try to stop Harry from returning to Hogwarts as Harry will encounter danger in this new year and Dobby does not want that. Honestly listening to Dobby's voice being narrated in the audiobook was amazing. <br><br>Regardless with all these warnings from Dobby, Harry manages to return back to Hogwarts by the rescue from the Weasely's and their flying car! I loved that scene in the movie and re-imagining it again was amazing. Not forgetting their journey to Hogwarts in the flying car and almost getting killed!<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1458963780ra/18553887.gif" width="200" height="350" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Upon their grand arrival at Hogwarts, they're warned for breaking the rules and what not and they meet their new <i>Defence Against The Dark Arts</i>, Professor Lockhart. I absolutely hated him and he was so phony! Like I could see through him right from the start. Hated that douche bag! All his miserable attempts at teaching in his lesson was hilarious too! <br><br>All the warnings from Dobby turned out to be true when there are people getting frozen and the cat being frozen as well. I just wonder how does Harry have such great guts to face such horrible creatures and mysteries. I would run away immediately. Maybe that's why I wouldn't end up in Gryffindor. Harry still doubts his placing in Gryffindor. He feels that maybe the sorting hat may have made a mistake in placing him in Gryffindor. But c'mon, we all know that's the right house for Harry. The Parseltongue moment was genius! How the author linked an event from the previous book and made it into something of a greater mystery. So smart!<br><br>I actually enjoyed this book but the lower rating is due to professor lockhart. I just hate him so much! I loved the adventures in this year of Hogwarts and all the msytery that took place. Easily my favorite series ever already!<br></span>  <a data-text-id="4550780854042867259" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div    <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=youth">youth</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=to-my-kids">to-my-kids</a>,           >            <span id="freeTextContainer9319066747107367723">This really is the worst book of the Harry Potter bunch, and its lack of quality isnU+2019t helped by its position in the series. For all its faults, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3584392.Myths_and_Symbols_in_J_K__Rowling_s_Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Myths and Symbols in J.K. RowlingU+00B4s Harry Potter and the PhilosopherU+00B4s Stone by Volker Geyer">PhilosopherU+2019s Stone</a> is a strong first novel and does a great job of sucking its readers in -U+2013 even the grown up ones -U+2013 and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Prisoner of Azkaban</a>, for its balanced mix of suspense, character development, and the first real glimpse of the world beyond Hogwarts and Privet Dr., makes it, for me, the best of the entire series. So <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Chamber of Secret</a>'s number tw</span>  <span id="freeText9319066747107367723" style="display:none">This really is the worst book of the Harry Potter bunch, and its lack of quality isnU+2019t helped by its position in the series. For all its faults, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3584392.Myths_and_Symbols_in_J_K__Rowling_s_Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Myths and Symbols in J.K. RowlingU+00B4s Harry Potter and the PhilosopherU+00B4s Stone by Volker Geyer">PhilosopherU+2019s Stone</a> is a strong first novel and does a great job of sucking its readers in -U+2013 even the grown up ones -U+2013 and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Prisoner of Azkaban</a>, for its balanced mix of suspense, character development, and the first real glimpse of the world beyond Hogwarts and Privet Dr., makes it, for me, the best of the entire series. So <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Chamber of Secret</a>'s number two position is a bad place to be in the Harry Potter world.<br /><br />What it boils down to is that <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Chamber of Secrets</a> is kinda dumb. This is the third time IU+2019ve read the book, and the first time IU+2019ve read it out loud to my kids, and it just doesnU+2019t work well. ThereU+2019s too much idiocy, really. The flying car is dumb. Hermione turning into a half-cat is dumb. Gilderoy Lockhart is dumb (though played extremely well by Kenneth Branagh in the movie). Aragog, the big blind spider, is dumb. And even Dobby is dumb long before he becomes interesting.<br /><br />For all these reasons the book feels outside the Potter universe. Almost everything in the other book makes sense to me, but this one is bizarre. What makes it worth reading, despite its dumbness, are the bits and pieces that hint at the world we'll see in the future: the introduction of Dobby and the house elves, the first taste of Tom Riddle, the beginning of the long road of love for Ginny and Harry, the naming of Azkaban as a prison that evokes terror, and the introduction of the surprisingly important Moaning Myrtle set us up for what's to come. <br /><br />Yes itU+2019s a crummy book, but it's not horrible. And kids love it, so that's gotta be worth more than one star (but only just).</span>  <a data-text-id="9319066747107367723" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/9246169-wanda?shelf=public-library">public-library</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1713766179" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5329142208688933352"><b>***WandaU+2019s Summer Carnival of ChildrenU+2019s Literature***</b><br /><br />While the excitement for the Harry Potter play just published is evident everywhere, I decided there was no better time to tackle book #2 in the Harry Potter series. I havenU+2019t much to say to add to the conversation regarding this seriesU+2014just that I can certainly see where it would be ideal to get reluctant readers engaged and excited about the reading process.<br /><br />This book was certainly well structured, producing tension in all the right places a</span>  <span id="freeText5329142208688933352" style="display:none"><b>***WandaU+2019s Summer Carnival of ChildrenU+2019s Literature***</b><br /><br />While the excitement for the Harry Potter play just published is evident everywhere, I decided there was no better time to tackle book #2 in the Harry Potter series. I havenU+2019t much to say to add to the conversation regarding this seriesU+2014just that I can certainly see where it would be ideal to get reluctant readers engaged and excited about the reading process.<br /><br />This book was certainly well structured, producing tension in all the right places and drawing the reader along quickly. The world building is definitely one of RowlingU+2019s strong suits, as HogwartU+2019s school feels like a place that I could maybe find my way around now. <br /><br />I also loved the fact that it made me think of other booksU+2014for example, the awful Dursleys reminded me strongly of Jane EyreU+2019s Aunt Reed and her family. And HarryU+2019s distrust of adults actually brought my most recent read, <i>The Goldfinch</i> to mind, and Theo with his reluctance to tell anything at all to an adult, feeling that nothing good would come of it! But I would have to say that Harry Potter is far easier to read.<br /><br />A charming tale. I was in my late 30s when Rowling published these booksU+2014how I would have loved them as a child!<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="5329142208688933352" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1713766179">  <td elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1477084025" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1477084025" />    <a title="Moraes the Bookworm" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm"><img alt="Moraes the Bookworm" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465866511p2/50389307.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1477084025?book_show_action=false">Jun 24, 2016</a>      <a title="Moraes the Bookworm" class="user" name="Moraes the Bookworm" href="/user/show/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm">Moraes the Bookworm</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=amazing-scenery-description">amazing-scenery-description</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=mild-angst">mild-angst</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=in-your-face-magic">in-your-face-magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=original-magic-system">original-magic-system</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=favourites">favourites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=contemporary">contemporary</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50389307-moraes-the-bookworm?shelf=memorable-secondary-characters">memorable-secondary-characters</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1477084025" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13311922280639122345">Some people tend to think this book is the worst in the whole series, but I disagree: I find this one of the best. Why? Well, of course it was incredible to be introduced to Hogwarts in the first book, with all its houses and classes and festive traditions, but a story needs more than that. To be good, a story needs depth and in order to gain depth the writer must come up with enough background either to the characters individually and to the story itself. I am sure this series could have gone</span>  <span id="freeText13311922280639122345" style="display:none">Some people tend to think this book is the worst in the whole series, but I disagree: I find this one of the best. Why? Well, of course it was incredible to be introduced to Hogwarts in the first book, with all its houses and classes and festive traditions, but a story needs more than that. To be good, a story needs depth and in order to gain depth the writer must come up with enough background either to the characters individually and to the story itself. I am sure this series could have gone down hill with no more than three books had the author not perceived it needed to be matured; young kids who had read and been enchanted by Sorcerer's Stone would get older, so the story had to get a few darker shades in order to keep up with their aging, otherwise audience would decline.<br><br><b>This book provides enough background for a second book, making you feel like reading more.</b> Of course we get to see Harry, Ron and Hermione back together at Hogwarts, but it's not all happiness and welcoming friends anymore. <i>The Chamber of Secrets</i> already at its beginning sends us a clear message: everything is different and there is real danger around. Most of the danger is caused by intangible old magic. After a very clever fashion, Rowling gives hints to what the story would become years later, as we see Harry and his friends discovering some of the dark past of some characters and of Hogwarts itself. Some of the messages seen in the first book are reinforced, like the value of friendship and power of loyalty, but other than that this book is much more complex, dark and mature.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1440118021i/15932686._SX540_.png" width="400" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I won't spend much effort trying to explain anything down to details, since pretty much everyone that hasn't been living under a rock knows most of the story. Instead, I will just cover a few points which I really enjoyed and which I didn't like that much while reading <i>The Chamber of Secrets</i>. First of all, despite the new shadowy atmosphere provided by the whole reopening of the Chamber of Secrets situation, <b>Hogwarts felt a lot more real and familiar here than in <i>Sorcerer's Stone</i>.</b> Part of it is due to the fact that, at some point, the fear of being attacked by the mysterious monster that was roaming around was so strong that everyone got closer to each other. There were lots of scenes describing people chatting on the common rooms, having snacks together; it felt cozy and warm, despite the palpable danger. The other aspect that I liked was <b>how difficult the author made every part of the investigation Harry, Ron and Hermione were running in order to find out the truth about the heir of Slytherin.</b> The fact that they had to work for months on the Polyjuice potion only enriched the story; made it more real - in most books about witches they just flick their wands and everything happens.<br><br>I've been trying to think about the negative aspects, anything that I don't like about <i>The Chamber of Secrets</i>. The only thing that comes to my mind, though, is the same complaint that would come from Ronald Weasley: spiders. I also suffer from arachnophobia, so those chapters full of spiders were a real pain for me to read without having to check every corner of my room every five seconds. Overall, though, this book is flawless.<br><br><u>  <b>Interesting quotes that I didn't include in the review:</b></u><br><i>  <blockquote>It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</blockquote></i><br></span>  <a data-text-id="13311922280639122345" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1477084025">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1477084025" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1477084025&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1477084025'><a id="like_count_review_1477084025" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1477084025?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">21 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1477084025" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1477084025" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=21&rating[page]=5&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1477084025&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1477084025" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1477084025, true, &#39;&#39;); id="reviewTextContainer237985844" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17294534930425554437">[November 11, 2015] Marking for re-read. I did not plan on reading this exactly two years after my first re-read, but here we are! This book is probably still my least favorite of the series, but I liked it more than ever. <br /><br />In this book we get our first real look at what Harry has to deal with during his entire time at Hogwarts and that is the ficklness of everyone's perception of him. Everyone turns on him so quickly and I think it's really interesting how at the Dueling Club people were willing</span>  <span id="freeText17294534930425554437" style="display:none">[November 11, 2015] Marking for re-read. I did not plan on reading this exactly two years after my first re-read, but here we are! This book is probably still my least favorite of the series, but I liked it more than ever. <br /><br />In this book we get our first real look at what Harry has to deal with during his entire time at Hogwarts and that is the ficklness of everyone's perception of him. Everyone turns on him so quickly and I think it's really interesting how at the Dueling Club people were willing to say that Harry was egging the snake on, simply because they were freaked out by his ability. <br /><br />The entire concept of "mudbloods" is another thing that got me really thinking this time around because Rowlling has this whole action adventure series, but manages to include these little bits of too much truth. It's prejudice and hate based on things people cannot control. <br /><br />There were a lot of little details I picked up on this time around that I just loved:<br /><br />- Ginny almost leaves her diary at home and they all have to go back so she can get it. SO CLOSE TO A NORMAL YEAR.<br /><br />- Dumbledore mentions here that a piece of Voldemort is in Harry and like WHAT? WE KNEW ALL ALONG? Pretty much.<br /><br />- Ginny's Valentine for Harry <3<br /><br />- Dumbledore taught Transfiguration, huh. <br /><br />- I love the Weasley's and I loved this first look at The Burrow and their home life. They are such amazing parents and substitute parents. <br /><br />- Can we just talk about how many of these elements come back? Azkaban and polyjuice potion and the sword of Gryffindor and the basilisk fang. So good. <br /><br />[November 13, 2103] Marked for re-read. I was surprised how much more I appreciated The Sorcerer's Stone and home much I was not as thrilled by the Chamber of Secrets upon re-read. I don't even have real reasons why, just ~*feelings*~. I'm pretty sure this is my least favorite of the series. But, still like, Harry Potter. </span>  <a data-text-id="17294534930425554437" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div It's so interesting reading about an average wizarding home.<br />I think Gilderoy Lockhart is an absolutely brilliant character and I love rereading all of his scenes, he is so sassy.<br />The plot is so clever and the whole story is filled with subtle clues and hints, which I love.              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16676459395338478045"><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is the number two of the entire Potter series in more ways than one. It's the turd of the lot. <br /><br />It's not terrible, but compared to the rest of the series <i>Chamber</i> has all the originality of a carbon copy of its predecessor, written to mirror and capitalize on the success of the first book.<br /><br />Yes Harry and schoolmates have moved on to their second year and there are occurrences that will later come into play in the bigger picture of the story, but in hindsight t</span>  <span id="freeText16676459395338478045" style="display:none"><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is the number two of the entire Potter series in more ways than one. It's the turd of the lot. <br /><br />It's not terrible, but compared to the rest of the series <i>Chamber</i> has all the originality of a carbon copy of its predecessor, written to mirror and capitalize on the success of the first book.<br /><br />Yes Harry and schoolmates have moved on to their second year and there are occurrences that will later come into play in the bigger picture of the story, but in hindsight these seem like mere happenstance that had to be cajoled into the plot once Rowling realized she had a hit on her hands that demanded sequels and a big finish. Perhaps I'm wrong. Maybe this was all part of her grand scheme from word-one. It just doesn't feel like it though. <br /><br />And the movie! Don't get me started on the movie...It's the only one we don't own. My wife refuses to buy it and has forbade me to gift it to her. I blame Kenneth Branagh. </span>  <a data-text-id="16676459395338478045" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div id="reviewTextContainer1671347090" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2774182993643361928"><i>Oh, well...if you had died, you'd have been welcome to share my toilet</i> U+2014Moaning Myrtle<br /><br />Harry Potter is inarguably the most empowered kid I've encountered in literature. In this sequel, his life is at risk once again, and the stakes are higher than ever, all because of a mythical monster hiding somewhere within Hogwarts. Add into the picture a house elf with a twisted messianic complex, and Harry's miserable initiation into puberty is complete. It's a good thing that our dear Harry isn't a typical</span>  <span id="freeText2774182993643361928" style="display:none"><i>Oh, well...if you had died, you'd have been welcome to share my toilet</i> U+2014Moaning Myrtle<br /><br />Harry Potter is inarguably the most empowered kid I've encountered in literature. In this sequel, his life is at risk once again, and the stakes are higher than ever, all because of a mythical monster hiding somewhere within Hogwarts. Add into the picture a house elf with a twisted messianic complex, and Harry's miserable initiation into puberty is complete. It's a good thing that our dear Harry isn't a typical twelve-year-old, and he has two best friends who will protect him at all cost. I'm so thrilled to have experienced another unforgettable adventure in this beautiful world of magic.<br /><br />P.S. I am not reading the series backwards. elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_674239573" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/674239573" />    <a title="Gregory" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22088998-gregory"><img alt="Gregory" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1444583829p2/22088998.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/674239573?book_show_action=false">Jun 07, 2015</a>      <a title="Gregory" class="user" name="Gregory" href="/user/show/22088998-gregory">Gregory</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810552" href="/book/show/7979789-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer674239573" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18135455457760184464"> There are stories written about magic and magical worlds,many stories with many characters about all kinds of fantasy worlds.But only this particular story about a young boy wizard managed to win my heart for eternity.The thing is,that J.K Rowling managed to create a world that is part of our own,well-hidden actually within our own,where everything is possible.Rowling's eye for detail and her vast imagination is what has me chained for good and binds my destiny with Harry's.She doesn't just</span>  <span id="freeText18135455457760184464" style="display:none"> There are stories written about magic and magical worlds,many stories with many characters about all kinds of fantasy worlds.But only this particular story about a young boy wizard managed to win my heart for eternity.The thing is,that J.K Rowling managed to create a world that is part of our own,well-hidden actually within our own,where everything is possible.Rowling's eye for detail and her vast imagination is what has me chained for good and binds my destiny with Harry's.She doesn't just write a story about a boy wizard.She managed to bring to life a whole new world full of possibilities.<br /> In this world Harry Potter is a young wizard of 12,studying at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry with his friends Ron and Hermione.In "Chamber of Secrets" everything we know and love about this world,and especially Hogwarts is changed.And this change begins with the arrival of Dobby the House Elf.Now, this right here is a sign of a brilliant imagination.What, you think elves are pretty easy to imagine when you think of fantasy books?No,this is different.I can't stress enough how much I love Rowling's characters,but it's the weirdest feeling ever,feeling that each and everyone of them can be 100% real and alive.The same applies for Dobby the House Elf.He has a personality,a certain attitude and certain traits.Plus he has his own story(revealed later in the book).These details make the world even more real.<br /> Then we have an amazing scene with a flying car,come on,a flying car!It is a dream coming true!Then a wonderful,wonderful,wonderful look at the Burrow,Ron's home.The Burrow.This is everybody's dream house.Don't even fight me with that.Housework done by magic,magical radio and news,degnoming gardens,living with the Weasleys,planning pranks with the twins,making Percy's life a misery,collecting Muggle stuff with Mr Weasley,playing Quidditch at the fields.This life could be wonderful!<br /> Then we have some hardcore fantasy were the amazing J.K Rowling actually has created a whole network for travelling from place-to-place.I want to spare you the fun so I'm not telling how they travel but it's pure gold!Then Diagon Alley once again stands as the most magical location on earth.The eye for detail makes you smell the air in the streets of the alley,makes you feel like it can really be true.<br /> I can go on and on forever with all the wonderful details and so,but now is time to talk about the main plot in "Chamber of Secrets".This Harry Potter book,like actually all of them,feels weirdly like a mystery novel.A threat is released in Hogwarts,a threat that no one really knows what it is,but that causes serious trouble,attacking students and causing panic.No one is safe,as long as the culprit behind these attacks is caught.Things go out of order,the students' lives are threatened,someone has to act,otherwise the school will be closed forever.<br /> And then we know who is responsible for all this.The Heir of Slytherin.And here is were the adventure takes flight!Our heroes go in search for the heir,try to solve the mystery of the Chamber of Secrets,not at all wanting to do so.But things move in mysterious ways,causing them to act this way.<br /> A thrilling adventure,once again in the familiar grounds of Hogwarts.But Hogwarts is no longer safe.Hogwarts is at its darkest.Yet,it feels great being back!Quidditch matches,magical classes,a duelling club,a deathday party,nigth adventures and a great mystery synthesize the atmosphere of this book and form a completely magical story.<br /> It feels great being back,I really can't get enough of this world,I miss it tremendously,I miss the characters and the locations and I really can't get enough of Harry's adventures in the Wizarding World.Every reread is a new experience!</span>  <a data-text-id="18135455457760184464" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1642170413?book_show_action=false">Oct 18, 2016</a>      <a title="Irene BU+00EC" class="user" name="Irene BU+00EC" href="/user/show/55991704-irene-b">Irene BU+00EC</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408845653" href="/book/show/29238041-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/55991704-irene-b?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1642170413" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13552239243713174344">This is my <i>second favorite book</i> in the series.<br /><br />Will it ever be easy for Harry to go back to Hogwarts? Not this year.<br />This time we have a flying car that brings Harry to school... with a lot of consequences.<br /><br />We are introduced to a bunch of new characters <i>(Arthur Weasley, Lucius Malfoy, Cornelius Fudge and see below)</i>, creatures <i>(like Fawkes, Aragog)</i> and places <i>(Flourish & Blotts, Knockturn Alley and Borgin & Burkes, Dumbledore's Office, the Slytherin's common room)</i>.<br /><br />First of all the <b>appearance</b></span>  <span id="freeText13552239243713174344" style="display:none">This is my <i>second favorite book</i> in the series.<br /><br />Will it ever be easy for Harry to go back to Hogwarts? Not this year.<br />This time we have a flying car that brings Harry to school... with a lot of consequences.<br /><br />We are introduced to a bunch of new characters <i>(Arthur Weasley, Lucius Malfoy, Cornelius Fudge and see below)</i>, creatures <i>(like Fawkes, Aragog)</i> and places <i>(Flourish & Blotts, Knockturn Alley and Borgin & Burkes, Dumbledore's Office, the Slytherin's common room)</i>.<br /><br />First of all the <b>appearance of Dobby the house-elf</b> (the feels), no need to say more.<br />We dive into a new school subject, herbology -where we learn about Mandrakes- with <i>professor Sprout</i>, head of Hufflepuff and we meet a crazy selfish hilarious <i>Gilderoy Lockhart</i>, the new Defence Against the Dark Arts' teacher.<br />In the book Lockhart is basically everywhere, an everywhere where he can prove that he did incredible things in the past and that he can save the world just with his presence...<br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[We explore a new dark part of the Hogwarts past, where the Chamber of Secrets had been opened, someone was expelled and worst of all, someone died.<br />Now looks like this is going to happen again, and that's why Harry, Ron and Hermione are trying in any way possible (even with Polyjuice Potion) to find more about what happened and most important who's behind all the mess that's happening at school, meanwhile they continue with their normal school activities.<br /><i>Harry discovers that he is a Parselmouth</i> thanks to Lockhart and his <i>Duelling Club</i> -even if for the rest of the school he is now the number one suspect.<br /><br />After putting the pieces together it's time to go and find the entrance to the Chamber of Secrets and find who's behind all of this, but first of all to save Ginny, who's missing and a creepy message about her was found in the corridor.<br />With Hermione petrified, Harry and Ron go into the Chamber with the one and only Gilderoy Lockhart. They learn that he has done nothing of what he said and that he is taking credit of other people who did those things.<br />And now it's time to meet Tom Riddle, heir of Slytherin and Lord Voldemort himself and the owner of that strange diary that Harry found.<br />Final battle now, Harry vs the Basilisk, the giant serpent that has petrified all those muggle-born students. Of course Harry won and he destroyed the diary of Tom Riddle, saving Ginny. <br />But there is one more rescue for Harry today... Dobby the house-elf is now free.<br />And this is one happy ending.<br />Harry saved the day once again, all the petrified students are free and Lockhart has erased all his memories so it's not a big deal anymore. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><b>Favorite Parts</b><br />> Dobby <br />> Gilderoy Lockhart<br />> Duelling Club<br />> Harry and Ron in the Slytherin's common room<br />> Harry in the Chamber of Secrets<br /><br />What I love about this book is that <i>there is a mystery to solve</i> (people found petrified and creepy messages written on the walls), <i>there are suspects</i> (who is the heir of Slytherin?) and it <i>gets a little darker</i> (follow the spiders, remember?). <br />The are as always the <i>"hidden" lessons that we can learn</i> with these books.<br /><br />I thinks I will repeat this for all the illustrated books but <b>the pictures are STUNNING!!!</b> Some of them are so colorful that is <i>pure joy</i>.<br />All those spiders gave me nightmares but that's fine, means that they were really well made, I guess lol<br />I only wanted a full page portrait of Tom Riddle which I hope I can find one day or another...<br /><br />Do I have to wait another full year before the next one?</span>  <a data-text-id="13552239243713174344" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>        <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/24190242-sara-freadom-library?shelf=high-fantasy">high-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" id="reviewTextContainer1064445938" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17384976427629133000">Actual rating 4.5 stars<br /><br />This review was originally posted at <a target="_blank" href="https://freadomlibrary.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">https://freadomlibrary.wordpress.com/</a><br /><br />MINI REVIEW <br /><br /><b>Critically</b><br /><br />Plot U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br />Writing Style U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br />Characters U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br /><b>Emotionally</b><br /><br />I definitely enjoyed this book a lot more than the first one. The plot was entertaining but still had some of the slower bits that frustrated me. It feels like it takes a long time to get to the meat of the plot which is annoying because obviously I already know what that is. However,</span>  <span id="freeText17384976427629133000" style="display:none">Actual rating 4.5 stars<br /><br />This review was originally posted at <a target="_blank" href="https://freadomlibrary.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">https://freadomlibrary.wordpress.com/</a><br /><br />MINI REVIEW <br /><br /><b>Critically</b><br /><br />Plot U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br />Writing Style U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br />Characters U+2013 4 out of 5 stars<br /><br /><b>Emotionally</b><br /><br />I definitely enjoyed this book a lot more than the first one. The plot was entertaining but still had some of the slower bits that frustrated me. It feels like it takes a long time to get to the meat of the plot which is annoying because obviously I already know what that is. However, the action started a lot earlier in the book as I was a lot more entertained and intrigued with the plot. There was a faster pace and it didnU+2019t take as long for everything to develop within the story as it did in the first book. Again, it was really exciting for me to see the contrast between the books and the movies and how things differ within adaptations. IU+2019m getting more into the series but not completely obsessed yet. Harry is growing on me, little by little. I love his determination and devotion to doing good things and I feel like weU+2019re getting to see more of his complexity with his flaws and vulnerability. Ron is a cutie with a temper though. I didnU+2019t realize how enraged he could get because he doesnU+2019t have that portrayal in the movie and I found that super interesting. Hermoine is also getting to me a bit, I must admit. SheU+2019s letting her guard down more and is also showing some sadness and vulnerability which is what I needed in the first book. I am so pumped to continue reading and finally fall more and more in love with this series.</span>  <a data-text-id="17384976427629133000" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return in the library's waiting list. Everyone hated me because there wasn't a time I didn't have one of the books with me.<br /><br />When I entered high school I stopped reading books -which I'm not proud of- but I definitely did watch the movies every once in a while. So, it has been seven years and I'm picking this book up again. It's as great as the first time, if not more. <br /><br />It doesn't matter that I know what's going to happen in the end, the annoying characters hasn't stopped being annoying and the mystery is as astounding as ever.<br /><br />I also had almost forgotten how much I hated Lockhart. I honestly believe I didn't to be reminded how infuriating he is.</span>  <a data-text-id="6591690802021279598" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/34926983-alisha-brown">alisha brown</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer8299927972685059606">Hi</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1754229378" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1754229378" />    <a title="Donna" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6217162-donna"><img alt="Donna" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1430955688p2/6217162.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1754229378?book_show_action=false">Oct 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Donna" class="user" name="Donna" href="/user/show/6217162-donna">Donna</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780545791328" href="/book/show/29241319-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6217162-donna?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6217162-donna?shelf=coming-of-age">coming-of-age</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1754229378" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5927879176542788935">Five stars for both a story that concludes with a most satisfying ending and the amazing illustrations that once again have brought the characters and their adventures to life.<br /><br />I'm very glad I waited to read this series in this form even though I must wait for the next book to be released each year, and even though it takes much longer to read each book this way with all the extra time spent staring at the wonderful artwork. It is sometimes splashed across entire pages or integrated with the text</span>  <span id="freeText5927879176542788935" style="display:none">Five stars for both a story that concludes with a most satisfying ending and the amazing illustrations that once again have brought the characters and their adventures to life.<br /><br />I'm very glad I waited to read this series in this form even though I must wait for the next book to be released each year, and even though it takes much longer to read each book this way with all the extra time spent staring at the wonderful artwork. It is sometimes splashed across entire pages or integrated with the text, but never intrusive. The illustrations only enhance the story and are a treat to view. I refused to peek ahead so I would be surprised. And I surely was surprised, starting with the table of contents which was crawling with life-like spiders. I'm a bit phobic of spiders, you see, and there were many of them in this book. I'm sure I'll see them in my dreams or should I say my nightmares? But there were many more illustrations to savor that were atmospheric or dramatic, or captured the essence of each character at any particular moment in time. One of my favorites was a very intuitive sketch of Draco on page 45 that showed not only a hint of malice, but a hint of vulnerability that elicited sympathy from me. Now that's artistic talent! <br /><br />As for the story, I enjoyed accompanying Harry as he began his second year at Hogwarts where he encountered a challenging mystery threatening people's lives along with the very existence of Hogwarts. This second year at school was a trying one for Harry, even before he headed off for classes due to the Dursleys determination to make him miserable over vacation. Most children wish for a break from school, but not Harry since Hogwarts is the closest thing to what he can call a home. He made many friends there his first year, but also enemies, it's clear, when he returns. And he learned a lot in his first year, especially about friendship, but during his second year, he learned even more, though not all of his lessons were learned in the classroom. In fact, his most important lesson his second year had nothing to do with defense against the Dark Arts or potion mixing. Instead, it came from Dumbledore himself when he told Harry, "It is our choices that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities." Along the way, Harry also learned about goodness, loyalty, courage, trust, patience, and tolerance, not to mention disappointment, prejudice, cowardice and the many forms in which evilness can masquerade. <br /><br />I wonder what Harry and his friends will learn in their third year. And I wonder what exciting illustrations Jim Kay will come up with to enrich their story. I intend to find out, same time next year. See you then! </span>  <a data-text-id="5927879176542788935" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext id="reviewTextContainer281196053" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4033064274155212201">I am of the steadfast opinion that the Harry Potter movies suck.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1420183804ra/13186889.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Chill your britches, fans, I love the actors just as much as you do. Tom Felton and Evanna Lynch are genuine fans of the franchise and fangirl as hard as we do. Daniel Radcliffe is surprisingly witty in interviews; who can forget his cutting remark on the sexualization of Emma Watson? And Emma remains one of my favorite celebrities. Her speech on feminism made me happy-dance.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1384020859ra/6748717.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>But I can't get over how much stuff they leave out from th</span>  <span id="freeText4033064274155212201" style="display:none">I am of the steadfast opinion that the Harry Potter movies suck.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1420183804ra/13186889.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Chill your britches, fans, I love the actors just as much as you do. Tom Felton and Evanna Lynch are genuine fans of the franchise and fangirl as hard as we do. Daniel Radcliffe is surprisingly witty in interviews; who can forget his cutting remark on the sexualization of Emma Watson? And Emma remains one of my favorite celebrities. Her speech on feminism made me happy-dance.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1384020859ra/6748717.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>But I can't get over how much stuff they leave out from the books. I was shocked that they only chose to include one memory of Tom Riddle in the Half-Blood Prince, disgusted that they kept pushing Harry/Hermione (let's pretend Jo never said she regretted Ron/Hermione), and full-on infuriated that they cut out Hermione's work with house-elf liberation.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1420183804ra/13186890.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The Chamber of Secrets is the sole movie I find is a fairly accurate adaption of the book. The Sorcerer's Stone was still finding its feet, and poor Emma acted like she was reciting lines for a school play. The second was where everything really began to come together, cementing its place as a multi-million-dollar franchise. <br><br>Of course, the film producers couldn't have done squat if the source material wasn't fantastic to begin with. The Chamber of Secrets may be my <i>second</i> least-favorite Harry Potter book (that honor goes to the Philosopher's Stone), but it's still caviar as far as books go.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1420183804ra/13186891.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Now onto the next one. id="reviewTextContainer741068891" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3023744526196143797"><b>First read: 2002<br>Re-read: 2010, 2012<br>Readalong: #MYPotteheadsReadathon on September, 2015.</b><br><br><u>Actual Rating: 5/5 MAGICAL  = 100%</u><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1443605305i/16384851._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="230" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><blockquote>U+201CI'll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I'm not there.U+201D</blockquote><br><br>This book proves how well someone can use their imagination. I was honestly more surprised that I didnU+2019t remember everything. Compared to the first book, where I was overwhelmed with nostalgia, in Chamber of Secrets it almost seemed like I was reading the book for the first time. This is also why I write re</span>  <span id="freeText3023744526196143797" style="display:none"><b>First read: 2002<br>Re-read: 2010, 2012<br>Readalong: #MYPotteheadsReadathon on September, 2015.</b><br><br><u>Actual Rating: 5/5 MAGICAL U+2605 = 100%</u><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1443605305i/16384851._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="230" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><blockquote>U+201CI'll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I'm not there.U+201D</blockquote><br><br>This book proves how well someone can use their imagination. I was honestly more surprised that I didnU+2019t remember everything. Compared to the first book, where I was overwhelmed with nostalgia, in Chamber of Secrets it almost seemed like I was reading the book for the first time. This is also why I write reviews on Goodreads, so I can remember what I liked and didnU+2019t like about a book. For Chamber of Secrets, I still felt that the pacing was excellent, every chapter was used perfectly. The build up of clues to solve the mystery was also well used. Of course, there was also character development for Voldemort, in the form of Tom Riddle. This of course, will be important later. Subtle, J.K....<br><br>Diving into book number two after finishing the Philosopher's Stone was so easy. The progression between the first two novels is fantastic - they have a similar tone and pacing, the length is very reasonable and isn't daunting. Unlike the last four books in the series, the first three feel like reads you could pick up and peruse whenever - they don't seem like such a commitment. I think this is also why these first few books, including Chamber of Secrets, are much more child friendly and appropriate. They capture the audience attention right from the beginning and keep a consistent pace which enables even those with short attention spans to become engrossed in the magical world of Hogwarts.<br><br><blockquote>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D<br></blockquote><br><br>My poor memory should not be an indication that this book was somehow less of a piece of the Harry Potter universe. It still stands on itU+2019s own. I appreciate it for the nuances of Dobby created to stop Harry from returning to Hogwarts, Hagrid, Dumbledore, and McGonagall were reaffirmed as good characters, Snape was Snape (I donU+2019t think we get a real sense of him until later). The point is, Year Two at Hogwarts is just as important as Year One, and just as important as Year Seven.<br><br>Again, like with my re-reading of book 1, I found myself forgetting how much humor was in this. Everything from Moaning Myrtle, to RonU+2019s broken wand (and slug curse), to all things Gilderoy Lockhart, had me laughing out loud. However, it was so interesting for my adult self to re-read and make all the connections in the world to book 7. This had to be the one book loaded with the most foreshadow. Everything from horcruxes, to hints of VoldemortU+2019s history, to Harry/Voldemort connections is here in this one. And again, IU+2019m awestruck at the level in which Rowling had the whole series mapped out.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1385993467ra/7270448.gif" width="400" height="160" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Review updated on September 30th, 2015.<br>Visit my website <a href="http://www.ameliaaxavier.com/2015/09/review-harry-potter-2.html" rel="nofollow">HERE</a> for full detailed review & discussion!</span>  <a data-text-id="3023744526196143797" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> href="/user/show/12824955-mari-ina">MariU+2113ina</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780747538486" href="/book/show/224912.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/12824955-mari-ina?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer424213851" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6167326314614417893">How can i start writing a review for a book that marked my pre-teen years so deeply and shaped the way i measure books even now, 15 years later? I'm not trying to exaggerate, not at all, but it's true. A high percentage of my generation will always be enthralled by the tales, of the young wizard with the oddly shapped mark on his forehead, no matter how many years will pass. Harry Potter is and always will be a cultural figure, a phenomenon, and for many the reason they start reading books.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430210974i/14693004._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I sti</span>  <span id="freeText6167326314614417893" style="display:none">How can i start writing a review for a book that marked my pre-teen years so deeply and shaped the way i measure books even now, 15 years later? I'm not trying to exaggerate, not at all, but it's true. A high percentage of my generation will always be enthralled by the tales, of the young wizard with the oddly shapped mark on his forehead, no matter how many years will pass. Harry Potter is and always will be a cultural figure, a phenomenon, and for many the reason they start reading books.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430210974i/14693004._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I still remember the day i got this one in my hands. It was 14th July of 2000 and i had my birthday, finally turning 9. My parents had arranged a big party in our new house and everyone was having fun. I was in my room playing with my friends when my Godmother came in bearing gifts. Clothes -meh-, gameboy cassettes -score- and a book -hmm-. That was't weird, i was always a keen reader even in my younger years, but this book was something else. <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430210974i/14693005.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I hadn't read the first one in the series yet but i didn't encountered a problem understanding the story. I started reading and reading and couldn't stop, not even to eat or sleep. I finished it in a day and a half, and after that i was forever a Potterhead.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430210974i/14693006._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The Chamber of Secrets is my favorite of the series along with the Goblet of Fire. I have read them both countless times, i can still recite big chunks out of them, or remember the exact pages my favorite scenes are in. Nowdays the same books stand in my bookcase with somewhat broken spines, looking proudly well-read and reminding me what a great story should be like.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1430212051ra/14693144.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Every character, every situation, every moral conundrum or ethical kerfuffle, every little detail, is so well thought out and brilliantly moulded that certainly blows your mind away. For me Hogwarts is an extended home and Harry, Hermione, Ron, Dumbledore, Professor McGonagall and even Snape<br>are a part of me. I'm very proud of them, and i'm absolutely sure they will always be a few of my favorite characters.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430212051i/14693145.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="6167326314614417893" href="#"  <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1520518868" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12104868408760380807">I'm starting to understand the hype surrounding Harry Potter. I loved this book; I enjoyed it so much more than the first one. So if that's an indication that the books get better and better as the series progresses, then I can't wait to read the next one. </span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/478650384" />    <a title="Erin U+2615 *Proud Book Hoarder*" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder"><img alt="Erin U+2615 createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/478650384?book_show_action=false">Jan 27, 2016</a>      <a title="Erin U+2615 *Proud Book Hoarder*" class="user" name="Erin U+2615 *Proud Book Hoarder*" href="/user/show/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder">Erin U+2615 *Proud Book Hoarder*</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=a-own-book-form">a-own-book-form</a>,               <a              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=s-king-recommends">s-king-recommends</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite"        <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=buddy-or-group-read">buddy-or-group-read</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer478650384" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15684948262770022937"><br /><b>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D </b><br /><br />It's not as easy to review such a well-loved and received series. The base story is already familiar to me since I've seen the movies. While the first followed the movie plot line closely, I noticed little scenes and extras in this book that didn't make their transfer to film. As before, Harry starts in the house of horrors, aka the Dursley residence, where they treat the kid so poorly I'm surprised he doesn't</span>  <span id="freeText15684948262770022937" style="display:none"><br /><b>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D </b><br /><br />It's not as easy to review such a well-loved and received series. The base story is already familiar to me since I've seen the movies. While the first followed the movie plot line closely, I noticed little scenes and extras in this book that didn't make their transfer to film. As before, Harry starts in the house of horrors, aka the Dursley residence, where they treat the kid so poorly I'm surprised he doesn't lose it and become an evil wizard himself. I can totally understand his desire to go to Hogwarts and escape that household, as morbidly amusing as it is (and it DOES make a good opening to these novels). <br /><br />Hogwarts was already fleshed out fully in 'Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone', but the charm and magic of the series came further alive in this second installment. It seems that Rowland has become more comfortable with writing itself, something that's hard for me to put a finger on exactly, but it's felt all the same. This book just read better, the previous mild cheese coating dusted away, leaving a fun joy behind. It's not all happiness and games, however; what good story would be? There's a darkness lurking around the corner and a mystery to solve.<br /><br />First, the professor Gilderoy Lockheart. The new Dark Arts teacher is introduced to this series, bringing numerous hilarious scenes that worked perfectly. What fun it is to follow the three kids through their classes - the clueless and boastful professor is a contrast to the experiences in the classroom of the slithering Snape who seems to have it against the kids. Hogwarts itself has such a strong presence in the novels - from the teachers, the classes, the studied subjects, Dumbledore, Hagrid and his cottage of tea and bizarre animals, that creepy Forbidden Forest with giant critters that nightmares are made of....and now let's throw in secrets passages and riddles and secret diaries. If that doesn't make a workable magical concoction, then I don't know what does.<br /><br />Since I'd experienced the story celluloid style, it held little surprise. I'm sure if I were naive going in, I'd have been surprised at the twist with the riddle for Tom Riddle, the discovery of the creature waiting in the bowels of the school, and the small twists that came about, but it was still a joy to experience in written form even if I knew the waiting answers. Pacing is kept up strong - you'd think it may be dull to spend so much time in a classroom, but not at all, for it unfolds naturally, applying in various ways to not only the main story of the Chamber, but to small details of the characters lives that will continue enriching the series.<br /><br />Harry is a wonderful protagonist - he's reasonable and decent but still a typical type of wizard kid willing to break small rules all for a spot of fun or dire circumstances. Ron is humorous without meaning to be, that unfortunate type who has bad luck and circumstance but shines with their general personality, and of course Hermione is a great confidante and friend you like to have around, especially when you aren't sure of the right curse to muster or potion to mix.<br /><br />Definitely recommended, hard to put down, I enjoyed this one more than the first. Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone wasn't bad, but something felt awkward to me, kind of like the beginning of one those odd school moments where teachers are trying to get kids to learn lame square dancing and then sectioning the kids into gender to dance together. I'm happy to say that awkwardness isn't present in Chamber of Secrets, and the heart of the series has started beating harder - it's not possible for me not to continue this series now. Let the magic continue!<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="15684948262770022937" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div Realmente no esperaba que me gustara tanto, pero paso. Mientras terminaba de leerlo no podU+00EDa dejar de pensar en la idea de adquirir los prU+00F3ximos libros de la saga porque es simplemente genial. <br />Me es necesario tambiU+00E9n compartir por este medio una anU+00E9cdota que me pareciU+00F3 curiosa y completamente mU+00E1gica en ese momento: estaba sentada leyendo "Harry Potter y la cU+00E1mara secreta" y viene mi madre con mucho (muchU+00EDsimo) entusiasm</span>  <span id="freeText7865903162252687655" style="display:none">Le doy unas limpias y bien merecidas 5 estrellas porque me dejU+00F3 maravillada. Realmente no esperaba que me gustara tanto, pero paso. Mientras terminaba de leerlo no podU+00EDa dejar de pensar en la idea de adquirir los prU+00F3ximos libros de la saga porque es simplemente genial. <br />Me es necesario tambiU+00E9n compartir por este medio una anU+00E9cdota que me pareciU+00F3 curiosa y completamente mU+00E1gica en ese momento: estaba sentada leyendo "Harry Potter y la cU+00E1mara secreta" y viene mi madre con mucho (muchU+00EDsimo) entusiasmo para pedirme que me asome a la ventana. Fue increU+00EDble mirar y poder contemplar una lechuza real merodeando por mi ventana. No, no es una historia inventada, es pura realidad. Creo que esa es la gran magia que trae la realidad, las coincidencias en los momentos justos. Fue raro ver a uno de mis animales favoritos tan de cerca, y mU+00E1s siendo que estU+00E1 ampliamente relacionado con el mundo de Harry Potter, fue un momento especial, al punto de que mis ojos se cristalizaron rU+00E1pido (aunque no llorU+00E9). Pero no voy a poder olvidar una de mis primeras experiencias con este libro. Sin duda fue algo que me inspirU+00F3 y me motivU+00F3 a continuar con la saga. Estoy dispuesta a terminarla este aU+00F1o, sU+00E9 que podrU+00E9, las historias son tan interesantes que es imposible bajar el libro una vez que lo estoy leyendo. </span>  <a    <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/624662635?book_show_action=false">Aug 27, 2016</a>      <a title="Thomas" class="user" name="Thomas" href="/user/show/2018505-thomas">Thomas</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=five-stars">five-stars</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=own-physical">own-physical</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer624662635" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10393501663819059531">I really, really like this series. I don't love it yet. But I'm on my way.<br /><br /><b>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</b> - Dumbledore, one of my favorite fictional mentors already.<br /><br />Time for my second informal <i>Harry Potter</i> review. Rowling continues Harry's quest to become the best wizard he can be at Hogwarts alongside his two best friends, Ron and Hermione. Great (though not beautiful or superbly sophisticated) writing, smart development of characters, and a</span>  <span id="freeText10393501663819059531" style="display:none">I really, really like this series. I don't love it yet. But I'm on my way.<br /><br /><b>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</b> - Dumbledore, one of my favorite fictional mentors already.<br /><br />Time for my second informal <i>Harry Potter</i> review. Rowling continues Harry's quest to become the best wizard he can be at Hogwarts alongside his two best friends, Ron and Hermione. Great (though not beautiful or superbly sophisticated) writing, smart development of characters, and a clever plot with laud-worthy foreshadowing motivate me to give this second installment five stars. One aspect of the book I loved was how Rowling built Harry's numerous conflicts. There was internal conflict (which house does Harry really belong in?), external conflict with other individuals (darn the Malfoy family and all of Slytherin) and external conflict with society (everyone suspecting Harry of being the heir of Slytherin). When all of these clashes are resolved by the end of the book it brings a strong feeling of satisfaction to those who empathize with Harry, the underdog from the start. <br /><br />Not to mention that I saw none of the plot twists coming - that shows how even adults can attain entertainment from this series, even if they have more foresight than I do. The quote I included above also exemplifies this book's appeal to all readers; it's a crosscutting theme amongst all ages that our actions make us who we are, not just what we're given by biology or God or whatever you believe in.<br /><br />Everyone tells me that these books get more and more enthralling as they progress. If so, <i>Harry Potter</i> may become one of my favorite series of all time. Better late than never, right?</span>  <a data-text-id="10393501663819059531" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div
