  <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer597852571" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8282308929821251777"><b>This is not a review</b>. (Sorry, Vivian!)<br />Allright, now that we've got this out of the way, I would like to point out three seemingly uninportant things that guaranteed this book five shining, sparkling stars, two of which (the things, not the stars) only appeared in the very last pages of the book.<br /><br />1. page 352/366<br /><blockquote> <i>For nearly a quarter of an hour [Harry] spoke into the rapt silence [...].</i> </blockquote><br />A <i>quarter of an hour</i>. Not <i>hours</i>, a seemingly endless amount of time, half a day, the whole night. A quarter of an</span>  <span id="freeText8282308929821251777" style="display:none"><b>This is not a review</b>. (Sorry, Vivian!)<br />Allright, now that we've got this out of the way, I would like to point out three seemingly uninportant things that guaranteed this book five shining, sparkling stars, two of which (the things, not the stars) only appeared in the very last pages of the book.<br /><br />1. page 352/366<br /><blockquote>  <i>For nearly a quarter of an hour [Harry] spoke into the rapt silence [...].</i></blockquote><br />A <i>quarter of an hour</i>. Not <i>hours</i>, a seemingly endless amount of time, half a day, the whole night. A quarter of an hour. In books, the recounting of adventurous events always seems to take an enormous amount of time, which always made me wonder: how fucking slowly do those people talk? Now this sentence here is what convinced me that J.K. Rowling not only is a great storyteller with an astounding imagination, but she <i>actively thinks</i> about what she's writing. What she says makes sense. In my book, that's what makes a winning writer.<br /><br />2. page 357/366<br /><blockquote><i>"It only put me in Gryffindor," said Harry in a defeated voice, "because I asked not to go in Slytherin..."<br />"</i>Exactly<i>, said Dumbledore, beaming once more. "Which makes you very </i>different<i> from <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Tom Riddle <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>. </i>[I know, I know, everyone's either read the books or seen the movies so it's public knowledge anyway, <i>shut up</i>.] <i>It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities."</i></blockquote><br />This book is bound to make children <i>think</i>. How many books are there out there that, while showing us adventures, magic and monsters, will also push ten-year-olds to ponder on good and evil and what makes us who we are? Obviously, this paragraph is one of a hundred, in this book only, that inspire such reflections. Draw your own conclusions.<br /><br />3. Dobby. He'll kick your ass. I don't think I need to say anything else.</span>  <a data-text-id="8282308929821251777" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div And this is really where you begin to see that Ron and Hermione are attracted to each other, whereas Harry and Ginny share the same sense of humor and the same type of bravery. </span>  <a <a title="U+271E U+0198 U+0454 U+2113 U+2113 U+0443 U+2727SU+0442 U+0454 U+2113 U+2113 U+03B1 U+044F ScU+044F U+03C5 U+0442 U+03B9 U+03B7 U+0443 U+271E" class="user" name="U+271E U+0198 U+0454 U+2113 class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/24407332-s-sc?shelf=that-is-what-i-call-an-ending">that-is-what-i-call-an-ending</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/24407332-s-sc?shelf=all-the-right-books-challenge">all-the-right-books-challenge</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/24407332-s-sc?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1370741489" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3447161124494806749"><blockquote> <i> <b>U+201CYou know what, Harry? If he doesnU+2019t stop trying to save your life heU+2019s going to kill you.U+201D</b> </i> </blockquote><br><a href="https://stellarscrutinyblog.wordpress.com/2015/12/04/review-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets-by-j-k-rowling/" rel="nofollow">Originally posted on Stellar Scrutiny Book Blog.</a><br><br>Ah, this one was really good! <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1437929204ra/15647251.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Despite having finished this book merely three weeks ago, I honestly can't recall much of the plot of Chamber of Secrets. I remember the beginning with Dobby, yes, the narcissistic teacher (Ha, who can forget him?), Quidditch matches, the Polyjuice Potion and Moaning Myrtle's bathroom, Draco being a git, Harry having to regro</span>  <span id="freeText3447161124494806749" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <i>    <b>U+201CYou know what, Harry? If he doesnU+2019t stop trying to save your life heU+2019s going to kill you.U+201D</b>  </i></blockquote><br><a href="https://stellarscrutinyblog.wordpress.com/2015/12/04/review-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets-by-j-k-rowling/" rel="nofollow">Originally posted on Stellar Scrutiny Book Blog.</a><br><br>Ah, this one was really good! <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1437929204ra/15647251.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Despite having finished this book merely three weeks ago, I honestly can't recall much of the plot of Chamber of Secrets. I remember the beginning with Dobby, yes, the narcissistic teacher (Ha, who can forget him?), Quidditch matches, the Polyjuice Potion and Moaning Myrtle's bathroom, Draco being a git, Harry having to regrow his bones (*shivers*), all the er, paralyzing, and the ending. Forgive me if I leave out any details.<br><br><b>I liked it. I liked it quite a bit</b> - maybe not as much as the first one, but I still enjoyed it, nonetheless. This one was without doubt, intenser (is that a word?) than the first, and a mystery begins to reveal itself. Harry, who I felt was slightly underdeveloped in the first novel, is beginning to blossom into an amazing protagonist, Ron and Hermione are just as spectacular as they were in the first book, Draco is as un-spectacular as he was in the first book, and we're introduced to Ginny! I can't wait to see how her character develops throughout the series.<br><br><b>  <i>    <u>The Plot</u>  </i></b><br><b>  <i>    <blockquote>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</blockquote>  </i></b><br>Harry, Ron, and Hermione are certainly in for an excited second year at Hogwarts! Speaking of which, I never really noticed the ironic name of the school until now. Hogwarts - it's warthog in reverse!<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449248446ra/17256282.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><i>I'm so clever...</i><br><br>The story takes off as Harry is visited at Privet Drive by a rather pestering house-elf named Dobby, who ceaselessly protests that something dreadful will occur if Harry returns to Hogwarts. Being the persistent (and stubborn) thirteen-year-old that Harry is, he ignores Dobby's warnings and proceeds to the school...by driving Mr. Weasley's magically enhanced, flying car there. Yep, that causes a wee bit of trouble.<br><br><b>  <i>    <blockquote>U+201COf all the trees we could've hit, we had to get one that hits back.U+201D</blockquote>  </i></b><br>But, ladies and gentlemen, that's only the tip of the iceberg. Not only, are students inscrutably being petrified to stone, but after everyone discovers that Harry is a parselmouth (a trait passed on from Salazar Slytherin, that allows you to speak to snakes) he is one of the prime suspects. Furthermore, rumors that the Chamber of Secrets, a mythical room that allegedly holds an appalling beast, may be opening once more...<br><br><b>  <u>    <i>The Characters<i></i></i>  </u></b><br><br>Ah, what more can I say about these characters? I still really really really like them all. Harry's internal and external conflicts and how he deals with them, along with his occasional burst of rage and frustration or dry retorts were more than amusing to read. Hermione's wits and haughtiness was just as perfect as it was in the first book, as was Ron's snappy remarks and bickering with Hermione...my teenage girl romance sensors are tingling.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449248624ra/17256295.gif" width="300" height="175" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>A little more light is shed on <s>Voldemort</s> He-who-must-not-be-named, and it'd be down-right lie for me to say I expected that ending. You know a book is really affecting you, when you shiver just thinking about the antagonist.<br><br><b>  <i>    <u>What I Loved</u>  </i></b><br><br>-Harry Potter! Yes, yes, yes! The first book was only 300 pages, so I can understand why Harry didn't develop that much, but in Chamber of Secrets, he begins to unravel many of his strengths and flaws.<br><br>-I still like the characters from the first book, and I really liked Dobby. Hehe, that little house-elf is fantastic. I was laughing so hard every time he tried to save Harry (hence, the quote on the top). Fred and George continued to crack me up, and Ron and Hermione are still perfect for each other.<br><br>-I <b>loved</b> how Riddle's Diary worked. I don't want to spoil anything, but the purpose it serves to the plot fascinated me!<br><br>-Quidditch! Or more specifically, Lee Jordan's commentary at the matches. Ha ha.<br><br>-The writing continues to entertain me, but I do wish there weren't so many dialogue tags with adverbs. But hey, this is a Middle Grade novel - you get what you pay for.<br><br>-The ending was done much better than Sorcerer's Stone. It was slightly more complex, and interested me more to be perfectly honest.<br><br><i>  <b>    <u>What I Didn't Love</u>  </b></i><br><br>-Geez, the pacing again! As I just mentioned, the ending was done much better that in the first novel, but the rest of the novel felt much too fast!<br><br>-I really wanted more Ginny! She really doesn't show up until the end. *sigh*<br><br>-Where's Dumbledore? I feel like he does nothing throughout the whole book and then just pops in at the end to explain everything to Harry. I really want to see more of him. <br><br><b>  <i>    <u>Final Thoughts</u>  </i></b><br><br>Upon finishing this book, I was lying awake at 1 in the morning pondering, what's next? If that isn't a clear indicator that I'm officially hooked on this series, then I don't know what is! I never really liked the idea of magic and wizards - I thought it was tacky and frankly, (don't come after me with pitchforks, please.) stupid. These books have surely changed my opinion on that!<br><br>If you haven't read this series yet, what are you waiting for? Read it! :D</span>  <a data-text-id="3447161124494806749" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=ebook_kindle">ebook_kindle</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1514738092" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8426861686554187569">I always have to wonder just what Lucius' plan was. It's said in later books, I believe, that he didn't know what he had... did he think it was just a cursed object? Or did he really think that the memory could have the power to do what he planned, not knowing that there was a real tether...? It just seems rather short-sighted on Lucius' part. <br /><br />Anyway, this is actually my least favorite of the series. I am far, far in the minority on this, but I just find Dobby to be a bit tiresome. I know why pe</span>  <span id="freeText8426861686554187569" style="display:none">I always have to wonder just what Lucius' plan was. It's said in later books, I believe, that he didn't know what he had... did he think it was just a cursed object? Or did he really think that the memory could have the power to do what he planned, not knowing that there was a real tether...? It just seems rather short-sighted on Lucius' part. <br /><br />Anyway, this is actually my least favorite of the series. I am far, far in the minority on this, but I just find Dobby to be a bit tiresome. I know why people love him, but each time I read this book, I like him a bit less. <br /><br />I did love Snape in this book, though he has a pretty small role in this one. His micro-expressions though... love them. When he finds out a student was taken into the Chamber, and he grips the back of the chair - that can be interpreted in so many ways. That is why I love Snape's character so much - he's not friendly, not likable, not charming... but throughout the whole series, his smallest moves and gestures can be seen to be whatever the viewer projects on them. He's like a blank slate. If you think he's evil, you will see his actions that way. I love that he's willing to walk that line. <br /><br />Also, this is the book that made me love Ron. His reaction when Hermione is attacked, and his slide down the wall when he hears about Ginny, are just perfect. His reaction when Hermione recovers is so adorable and great. It's one of my favorite moments in the book, and it's literally like one sentence long. (I love Ron & Hermione together. Harry and Hermione? No way.) <br /><br />Anyway... I'm not reading these in my usual no-interruptions, straight through method and it feels a bit weird, but whatever. I'm going with it. itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/177283411" />    <a title="Vanessa" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4636758-vanessa"><img alt="Vanessa" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1472996735p2/4636758.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/177283411?book_show_action=false">Sep 22, 2016</a>      <a title="Vanessa" class="user" name="Vanessa" href="/user/show/4636758-vanessa">Vanessa</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408855669" href="/book/show/22841998-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer177283411" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17829285027612854326"><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> has always been one of my favourite books (and movies in the series). This seems to be a bit of an unpopular opinion, with a lot of people citing this as their least favourite, but I honestly can't understand why. This has everything I love about the series - humour, darkness, and a hell of a lot of heart.<br /><br />I couldn't give this book anything less than five stars, and a glowing review. I am absolutely loving returning to these childhood favourites as an adult</span>  <span id="freeText17829285027612854326" style="display:none"><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> has always been one of my favourite books (and movies in the series). This seems to be a bit of an unpopular opinion, with a lot of people citing this as their least favourite, but I honestly can't understand why. This has everything I love about the series - humour, darkness, and a hell of a lot of heart.<br /><br />I couldn't give this book anything less than five stars, and a glowing review. I am absolutely loving returning to these childhood favourites as an adult - I was immediately enveloped in the story, and it was definitely a real comfort to read curled up on my sofa at home in the evenings. The fact that this book in the series already started to betray the much darker themes that would come into the later books is something I love - there is something so chilling about the bloodthirsty Harry hears, the Petrified students, and the messages daubed in blood. And one of my all-time favourite things about this book? Gilderoy Lockhart. He is honestly one of Rowling's best creations I think, and it doesn't even bother me that Kenneth Branagh now features heavily in my mind whenever I read his scenes, because it was perfect casting in my opinion.<br /><br />What else can I say? I love this book, I love this series. Onto my re-read of <i>The Prisoner of Azkaban!</i></span>  <a data-text-id="17829285027612854326" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8962463913532501745">Wow, this was so so good!!!<br /><br />At first, I was a little iffy about it because the characters are so young. It took me a bit to get into, but once they arrived at Hogwarts, I loved it! I love how the writing really draws you in and gives such a beautiful atmosphere. I loved all of the descriptions of the school, it really engaged my imagination.<br />I was surprised by how many times this book.. well.. surprised me! I thought I would be able to figure everything out, but the plot is very intricate. The twi</span>  <span id="freeText8962463913532501745" style="display:none">Wow, this was so so good!!!<br /><br />At first, I was a little iffy about it because the characters are so young. It took me a bit to get into, but once they arrived at Hogwarts, I loved it! I love how the writing really draws you in and gives such a beautiful atmosphere. I loved all of the descriptions of the school, it really engaged my imagination.<br />I was surprised by how many times this book.. well.. surprised me! I thought I would be able to figure everything out, but the plot is very intricate. The twists really got me, and once the mysteries were solved, it was cool to think back on all of the foreshadowing. I love when little details that don't seem important come back later to play a big role, and that's what this story does.<br />I had a blast going on this journey with Harry in his second year, and I'm excited to continue on!</span>  <a data-text-id="8962463913532501745" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div id="reviewTextContainer1332711740" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16179977369761192497"><b>4,5 stars!</b><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1428101160i/14367285._SX540_.jpg" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><s>I'M BACK!!!!!</s><br><br><b>What can I say about this amazing series that completely steal my heart?</b> It doesn't matter if I'm stressed and sick as I was in this past one week and a half - this book completely soothes me. For some people, Harry Potter may just be a magical story that is far from reality and that they only find interesting. For me, it's a way to travel to another world and get lost. It's rooting for characters, being scared for them and trying to guess what is going on. It's... it's tu</span>  <span id="freeText16179977369761192497" style="display:none"><b>4,5 stars!</b><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1428101160i/14367285._SX540_.jpg" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><s>I'M BACK!!!!!</s><br><br><b>What can I say about this amazing series that completely steal my heart?</b> It doesn't matter if I'm stressed and sick as I was in this past one week and a half - this book completely soothes me. For some people, Harry Potter may just be a magical story that is far from reality and that they only find interesting. For me, it's a way to travel to another world and get lost. It's rooting for characters, being scared for them and trying to guess what is going on. It's... it's turning off everything around you and being happy to do it. <br><br><b>  <i>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</i></b><br><br>This book is different from all the other books because we are shown a side to <s>Voldemort</s> (you-know- who) for the very first time. His time as a student throughout his diary, which is found by Harry and leaves him <i>(and us)</i> very confused and eager to know what does he has to do with everything going on in Hogwarts. (people are being petrified, guys). This book also has <b>scaryyyyy</b> monsters all over it! And we see how Harry and Ron deal with not having Hermione's 100% cleverness beside them. <br><br><b>U+201CHearing voices no one else can hear isn't a good sign, even in the wizarding world.U+201D</b><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1436719630i/15495672.jpg" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>When I was a child, I used to play Harry Potter with my brother and cousins. The point was: we would pick our "wands" (our school pens) and throw spells at each other and won the person that "defeated" the most <b>and</b> who used as many different spells as possible. And I have to say, if I had read this at the time or watched this movie more, I would have won a thousand times. <b>This book is so rich in spells!</b> Most of them bad hehe. This is due to the fact that this has <b>a lot</b> of action and things that you didn't expect in a million years happen and you're left speechless. And I love some good adventure-fantasy story. <br><br>Yeah, Harry Potter is a total must-read. Besides, I love Dumbledore from movie one and two so much that I kept reading this and imagining him as Dumbledore. With all his wisdom, he reminds me a lot of my grandpa. And my grandpa loved Harry Potter, so it's only fitting, huh? <br></span>  <a data-text-id="16179977369761192497" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> I have watched it when I was too young to understand the story of the movies.<br />Unpredictable because: I didn't know what would be the story of this book. When I watched its movie I didn't understand its story except for the scenes of the movie are still in my mind. I will watch the movies of the whole series after reading its books. I haven't HP movies except for one.<br /><br /><b>  <u>OVERVIEW</u></b><br />After the coming of Harry at Hogwarts, strange thing happens. Students are been paralized by a mysterious way. Nobody knows who does that. They(Harry, Ron and Hermione) find one clue, a writing on the wall which reads:<br />"Chamber of Secrets has been opened. Enemies of the Heir, beware"<br />In this book they are finding what the chamber of secrets is? OR What does it means by the 'Enemies of Heir'<br /><br /><b>Don't open it, if you don't want any revelation!</b><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<br />Chamber of Secrets is made by Salazar Slytherin, one of the founders of Hogwarts, to remove all the Muggle-born(people without magic) students from the Hogwarts.<br />Chamber of Secrets can only be opened by the true heir of Salazar Slytherin. <br />The chamber has been open before. Both times there is the same man. But this time Heir of Slytherin uses someone to open it.<br /> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><b>  <u>THINGS I LIKED</u></b><br /><br /><b>Quidditch Match</b><br />It was great. This time this was more difficult than before. What a powerful thing that was! <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ Just look in its eyes and you will be DEAD <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><i>I liked Every thing in this book!</i><br /><br /><br /><b>  <u>THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE</u></b> (Not That Much)<br /><br />-This book was little slow. Almost half of the book, I didn't understand why I am reading this book, WHY? Because nothing special happened. But I didn't give up because its slowness was not that bad to force me to leave this book. It was just feeling natural to me.<br />-Lockhart, I want to kill this character!! He was just unbearable for me to read. I think author was just trying to show us that some people just take credit of others' success and can't do anythings on their own..<br /><br /><i>I totally love this book even with the things I didn't like.</i><br /><br />I would like to give this book:<br /><b>*** 5 Life Long Stars ***</b><br /><br />I recommend this series to everybody. You will not repent own your decision.<br /><br /><b>Point out my mistakes or my misunderstanding about this book, if there are any. I would be happy to see that!</b><br /><br /><i>Thanks for your attention!</i><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10736242886795852189" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1381728-maxwell?shelf=i-own-it">i-own-it</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1381728-maxwell?shelf=2014">2014</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1116981984" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10596995984582888006"><i>Reread November 2014</i><br /><br />While this is probably one of my least favorites of the series, it's still a <b>fantastic</b> book. I can't say for sure why I don't love it as much as the others, but it's just never stood out to me.<br /><br />However, upon rereading it, I am reminded again how great Rowling is at developing a story arc! There are so many hints to later parts of the series in this book! Especially with Tom Riddle showing up, the diary, hints of Ron's affection for Hermione, and overall just building up the ch</span>  <span id="freeText10596995984582888006" style="display:none"><i>Reread November 2014</i><br /><br />While this is probably one of my least favorites of the series, it's still a <b>fantastic</b> book. I can't say for sure why I don't love it as much as the others, but it's just never stood out to me.<br /><br />However, upon rereading it, I am reminded again how great Rowling is at developing a story arc! There are so many hints to later parts of the series in this book! Especially with Tom Riddle showing up, the diary, hints of Ron's affection for Hermione, and overall just building up the characters and storyline. It's also really fun to see things of importance show up early in the story come into significance later on.<br /><br />Here are some thoughts on things I noticed or didn't remember about this book while I was reading it:<br />-Like in one of the Harry Potter video games, Ron and Harry de-gnome the Burrow's garden at the beginning of the book. <br />-Hermione's parents actually go to Diagon Alley and exchange Muggle money at Gringott's!<br />-Why wasn't Nearly Headless Nick's deathday party in the movie? Also he died in 1492 which is when Columbus 'discovered' America. Significant?<br />-"And some old witch in Bath had a book that you could never stop reading! You just had to wander around with your nose in it, trying to do everything one-handed." (p.231) Sounds familiar.<br />-I really wish they had the Valentine's Day party in the movie, with all the dwarves walking around dressed as cupids and delivering love messages.<br />-Aragog is literally my biggest fear.<br />-Apparently Dumbledore, back in the day, was a Transfiguration professor at Hogwarts.<br />-And finally, I knew Voldemort was an heir of Slytherin, duh, but I didn't realize he was the <i>last</i> heir of Slytherin. Dun dun duuuun.<br /><br /><b>5/5 stars</b> because even when it's my least favorite of the seven, it's still perfect.</span>  <a data-text-id="10596995984582888006" href="#" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/582889968" />    <a title="Angela" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4255477-angela"><img alt="Angela" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1398251387p2/4255477.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/582889968?book_show_action=false">Mar 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Angela" class="user" name="Angela" href="/user/show/4255477-angela">Angela</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/13563648-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=2013-read">2013-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=2013-read-sequels">2013-read-sequels</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=kindle">kindle</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4255477-angela?shelf=2016-read">2016-read</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer582889968" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17173528938105396805">Eh.<br /><br />Don't get me wrong. I wouldn't want to give the wrong idea. This is Harry Potter - and thus a part of my FAVORITE series, ever. However, it's probably my least favorite book (oddly, not my least favorite movie). There are a few reasons for this, the biggest one being that it came directly after Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.<br /><br />Book 1 was SO amazing, so entrancing, that I don't know that there ever would have been a single book that could live up to it. So, immediately, from the start, Ch</span>  <span id="freeText17173528938105396805" style="display:none">Eh.<br /><br />Don't get me wrong. I wouldn't want to give the wrong idea. This is Harry Potter - and thus a part of my FAVORITE series, ever. However, it's probably my least favorite book (oddly, not my least favorite movie). There are a few reasons for this, the biggest one being that it came directly after Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.<br /><br />Book 1 was SO amazing, so entrancing, that I don't know that there ever would have been a single book that could live up to it. So, immediately, from the start, Chamber of Secrets suffers. It's actually not saying too much that it's my least favorite, because it's still a solid four-stars, but full-disclosure and all.<br /><br />Confession: I don't like Dobby. I never have. And even though I have heart-felt emotions regarding him later in the series, it doesn't ever negate the fact that I just do not like him.<br /><br />What I really like here is that, in this book, you are first given the sense that this series is more than just books connected by characters, but there's an overall storyline and plot running throughout. That it's not just going to be book after book after book of the same thing, but that as our characters age, and the world changes, new and interesting and dangerous things are going to start happening.<br /><br />Then there's the new characters that start getting introduced. In this book, it's primarily Dobby (a house-elf - and even though I don't like him, I do LOVE the plot-lines that his species opens up later in the series), and Gilderoy Lockhart. By the way - Kenneth Branaugh is brilliant as Lockhart.<br /><br />Lockhart is the new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher at Hogwarts, a position that he seems to be eminently qualified for. Look, I know a lot of people hate Lockhart, I do too, actually, but I love to hate him. Seriously love it. He's a fantastic character, even though he is a prat, or maybe because he is.<br /><br />Confession 2: I'm not the biggest Ginny fan. Especially not here in the beginning. I feel for her, but the hero-worship...Ugh. Thankfully that doesn't last much beyond this book.<br /><br />But there are so many things that I enjoy here, too!<br /><br />1. Peskipiksi Pesternomi<br />2. Potion brewing in the bathroom<br />3. Hermione <3<br />4. Dueling Club - <3 Snape<br />5. Fawkes!<br />6. Dwarves dressed as "Cupids" to deliver Valentines<br />7. The thought of asking Snape for a love-potion!<br />8. Harry's Valentine<br />9. The Mystery<br /><br />The mystery is actually quite good - something I've finally been able to realize and acknowledge on this last re-read. It unravels quite beautifully, and with an awesome amount of building suspense. <br /><br />Now, onto one of my absolutely favorites: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. YES!<br /><br />Review also available at <a href="http://thebookeaters.net/2016/03/11/review-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets/" rel="nofollow">The Book Eaters</a><br /><br /><br /><br />Previous review:<br />I've gotta be honest. This was always my least favorite book, ever since the first time I read it. But on this re-read, I was enchanted, enthralled and left wondering what the hell my problem was previously.<br /><br />Once again I have no hope of doing a review of this book justice.<br /><br />On to my favorite in the series: <i>Prisoner of Azkaban</i>!! <br /><br />Part of the <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/559980580">EPIC 2013 Harry Potter Group Read</a></span>  <a Of course, Rowling never really gets the process of stream</span>  <span id="freeText9931395022796215915" style="display:none">In her second outing, Rowling builds up her confidence (and relationship with her publisher) enough to begin her signature page number crawl. Unfortunately, for this book, her chaotic plotting means that the further length just becomes more scattered moments. <br /><br />Despite some interesting twists and concepts, this is the weakest entry in the series. It betrays a utilitarian sense of plot and worldbuilding, in that it expands the story little. Of course, Rowling never really gets the process of streamlining or simplification into her literary arsenal, but later books in the series come to use her meandering style more to her benefit.<br I can't help but adore these characters and the creature in the chamber will always unnerve and scare me to this day, because of how much it did when I was a child. <br />I just adored the scenes like the Deathday party which aren't actually in the films and being able to relive them is always fascinating and fun. I think that</span>  <span id="freeText12790178732463838271" style="display:none">Of course this gets another 5* rating but this was probably a little higher than the first book overall as I just loved seeing more of the characters and the classes and world. I can't help but adore these characters and the creature in the chamber will always unnerve and scare me to this day, because of how much it did when I was a child. <br />I just adored the scenes like the Deathday party which aren't actually in the films and being able to relive them is always fascinating and fun. I think that the quality of writing has also improved vastly in this book from the first and I know this only continues as it goes on, so I'm looking forward to finishing a few more in the series very soon. <br />Of course highly recommended!! 5*s</span>  <a data-text-id="12790178732463838271" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1469645452?book_show_action=false">Jul 13, 2016</a>      <a title="Councillor" class="user" name="Councillor" href="/user/show/40792319-councillor">Councillor</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=20th-century">20th-century</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=uk-ireland">uk-ireland</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=read-2015">read-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=action-adventure">action-adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=rated-3-and-a-half-stars">rated-3-and-a-half-stars</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=children">children</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=library">library</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=friendship">friendship</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=the-2nd-book-in-a-series">the-2nd-book-in-a-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=school-setting">school-setting</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1469645452" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12495769170542224965">How do you review a beloved book which nearly everyone in this world seems to adore and which you wanted to love as well, but ended up being slightly disappointed with? "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" is the second book out of the HP series and follows Harry, Ron and Hermione through their adventures during their second year in Hogwarts. After reading (and enjoying) the first book some days ago (and just about ten years too late), my expectations for this second book were probably too</span>  <span id="freeText12495769170542224965" style="display:none">How do you review a beloved book which nearly everyone in this world seems to adore and which you wanted to love as well, but ended up being slightly disappointed with? "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" is the second book out of the HP series and follows Harry, Ron and Hermione through their adventures during their second year in Hogwarts. After reading (and enjoying) the first book some days ago (and just about ten years too late), my expectations for this second book were probably too high, as it is often the case with second installments in a series.<br /><br />J.K. Rowling delved deeper into the world of Harry Potter, his friends and his enemies, but in the end, I felt as if we didn't learn many new things about this world. Apart from some very interesting bad-ass moments, the character development lacked some of its profound depth from the first book and ultimately made me consider the book as a transition phase between Harry Potter as a child and a teenager.<br /><br />However, don't you think I didn't enjoy or like it! It was still a great book, a magical world, an exciting plot, but its flaws emerged a little bit more apparently and were unable to fulfil my expectations in their entirety. Draco Malfoy continues to be annoying, not because of the character's annoying appearances, but because of his character traits being nearly non-existing. It can be argued that it is difficult to create full characters out of children, but J.K. Rowling succeeded with trying this procedure with Harry, Ron, Hermione and even Ginny, so why not with Draco? Hopefully, his character is going to be explored in more profundity during the other novels.<br /><br />It seems like I keep defending my relatively low rating of this novel, but Goodreads describes a three-star-rating as 'liked it', and I absolutely did. It simply was no 'really liked it' or 'it was amazing', so I will lower my expectations a little bit and hope to be able to award five stars again after reading the next book.<br /><br /><blockquote>When I'm 80 years old and sitting in my rocking chair, I'll be reading Harry Potter. And my family will say to me, 'After all this time?' And I will say, 'Always.'</blockquote><br />Isn't this a lovely statement? Sources say Alan Rickman created this quote, but others insist on the quote being misattributed, so I'll just leave it at that and turn to the third novel of the Harry Potter series.</span>  <a data-text-id="12495769170542224965" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1469645452">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1469645452" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1469645452&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1469645452'><a id="like_count_review_1469645452" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1469645452?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">44 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1469645452" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1469645452" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=44&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1469645452&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1469645452" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1469645452, true, &#39;&#39;); id="reviewTextContainer624327642" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12629846971492241452">I am one of those people who grew up with the Harry Potter movies rather than with the books (I'm not ashamed to admit, either, that I loved the movies and still do, despite them missing some of the awesomeness), and I was one of those who refused to read the books because I didn't want to be part of the hype and it actually made me sick. Gratefully, 4 years ago I decided to give in. The big surprise was that I ended up loving the series, the story but most of all, its characters.<br /><br />That said, I mu</span>  <span id="freeText12629846971492241452" style="display:none">I am one of those people who grew up with the Harry Potter movies rather than with the books (I'm not ashamed to admit, either, that I loved the movies and still do, despite them missing some of the awesomeness), and I was one of those who refused to read the books because I didn't want to be part of the hype and it actually made me sick. Gratefully, 4 years ago I decided to give in. The big surprise was that I ended up loving the series, the story but most of all, its characters.<br /><br />That said, I must continue. This second installment is not the best of them, yet it's still very good. The mystery was not so easy to guess, and god, the characters! I love them all! Except, of course, 2 of them.<br /><br /><b>#1: Mr. Gilderoy Lockhart.</b> Because I am not fond of bad teachers. I seriously abhor them. I wanted this fraud of a man dead ever since he appeared for the first time. The worst part is that he taught what probably was the most important class of them all.<br /><br /><b>#2: Dobby.</b> Even though I grew fond of him later, you have to admit he was very annoying t the beginning. And please someone tell me I'm not the only one who doesn't fall for his almost-killed-Harry-but-did-it-with-good-intentions-so-I-will-punish-myself-for-it bullshit.<br /><br />Originally, my rating was 4 stars, but then I decided I should round it to 5 because I really truly love this. I think I miss the characters' innocence already and want to dive in again, but I will hold myself from doing so. U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/13603662-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=favorite-series">favorite-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=ebooks">ebooks</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1405697636" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13105315206621596305">This book was slightly more different from the movie as opposed to Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone and its film adaptation but I still loved reading about the infamous Chamber of Secrets nonetheless.<br /><br />I loved the concept of the Tom Riddle and the diary! I was, and still am, so amazed by the magic in this world. After reading the second book, I sort of developed a kind of fondness or some unusual respect for Voldemort as a character. Of course, everything he has done was unforgivable but I ca</span>  <span id="freeText13105315206621596305" style="display:none">This book was slightly more different from the movie as opposed to Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone and its film adaptation but I still loved reading about the infamous Chamber of Secrets nonetheless.<br /><br />I loved the concept of the Tom Riddle and the diary! I was, and still am, so amazed by the magic in this world. After reading the second book, I sort of developed a kind of fondness or some unusual respect for Voldemort as a character. Of course, everything he has done was unforgivable but I can't help but feel pity of him. In his youth, he really was a bright wizard who just had a troubled past that rippled and created the monster that he would later become. I always wondered what spurred his hatred for muggle-borns and this book really clarified that question for me.<br /><br />And now, rather than seeing Voldemort as this all-powerful evil wizard, I just view him more as a tragic character who had such a potential to truly be the greatest wizard in the world that he so wished to be, but because of his past and his choices, it twisted him and transformed him into the very epitome of evil starting at such a young age.<br /><br />I loved this book so much more than the first! I can already tell that these books are starting to take a more darker mood compared to Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. Reading this series really has me reminiscing my childhood! :P</span>  <a data-text-id="13105315206621596305" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> seen this movie also haha, so remember a lot of things that happened, but it was a pleasure remembered !<br><br><br>I think in this book <i>  <b>Harry</b></i> behaves more mature way, even though it is a child, of course, he has facing the people who attacking him without hesitation and breaking the rules even more, I really liked that , I think it's a very solid main character with unlimited possibilities.<br>Anything can happen in this world.<br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471536608ra/20069350.gif" width="500" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>The plot this time is centered in the chamber of secrets, its meaning and what it contains, what I found interesting to read. The last chapters of the book are the best, in my opinion.<u>One of the things I enjoy most about these books is how easy it is to read it, how simple the story seems when at the same time is so complex and even though the plot focuses on one thing, as its title says, I think the writer manages to play many different topics as well, without changing the main point</u> <br><br><br><i>  <b>    <blockquote>U+201CHearing voices no one else can hear isn't a good sign, even in the wizarding world.U+201D</blockquote>  </b></i><br><br><br>I love <i>  <b>Ron and Hermione</b></i> alike, their personalities are so different and somehow have managed this beautiful friendship. The way in they care each other and while and both have these little disagreement and discussions is adorable. don't know why, but I get a lot of tenderness.<br>I can't wait to see what will happen with the characters as they grow. And how that will influence their relationships and their lives, their families and Hogwarts.I'm excited. :)<br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471536608ra/20069351.gif" width="500" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br><i>  <b>Hagrid and Dumbledore</b></i> are still my favorites when I read it , I think they have the most interesting parts of the plot even though they are minor characters, they are always involved in some way.<br>Hagrid is an adorable and funny character, he's always getting into trouble xD. Dumbledore continues to have the best lines in history, with his great wisdom and kindness has earned a place in my heart :).<br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1466960261ra/19535608.gif" width="600" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>I'm still not sure about <i>  <b>Ginny</b></i>, not even what her rol in the plot and although this time has had a very important role, her personality makes me a little upset, I don't know, maybe become a character stronger with time, but still don't know how I feel about her. Her complete obsession with Harry it was for me at times a little creepy, it's a girl and she is in love , I know that, but at times the writer describes her , and I imagine a stalker (?. I said it.<br><br><br><u>So this is getting better for my guys, so no doubt, I'll continue with the saga :D. I am increasingly excited about what will happening :)</u><br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="1048295341213730602" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/4273354" />    <a title="Swaps55" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/251287-swaps55"><img alt="Swaps55" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1376517361p2/251287.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/4273354?book_show_action=false">Aug 16, 2007</a>      <a title="Swaps55" class="user" name="Swaps55" href="/user/show/251287-swaps55">Swaps55</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/251287-swaps55?shelf=scifi-fantasy">scifi-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/251287-swaps55?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer4273354" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18394558106495361038">While the story fits neatly together and again, her imagination is fantastic, the flat characters that play to extreme stereotypes take a lot of the enjoymeny out of this story. <br /><br />There is no excuse for Gilderoy Lockhart. Granted, his fame obsession and ludicrous self-absorption make for some amusing Rowling-esque moments that make the series good (such as a dozen Lockharts running for cover in the photo frames with rollers in their hair), but at the expense of the reader's patience. This degree o</span>  <span id="freeText18394558106495361038" style="display:none">While the story fits neatly together and again, her imagination is fantastic, the flat characters that play to extreme stereotypes take a lot of the enjoymeny out of this story. <br /><br />There is no excuse for Gilderoy Lockhart. Granted, his fame obsession and ludicrous self-absorption make for some amusing Rowling-esque moments that make the series good (such as a dozen Lockharts running for cover in the photo frames with rollers in their hair), but at the expense of the reader's patience. This degree of narcissism, even if plausible in the real world, stretches my suspension of disbelief too far. Like every page with Malfoy on it, I'd rather flip past them than read them. <br /><br />The greatest problem I have with this series is the two dimensional villains (or irritating Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers). Good villains should draw out some sort of sympathy in the reader, or reveal at some point their humanity. At the very least, you should be able to understand why they are the way they are, and that back story allows you to look at them from a different perspective. This moment never happens for Lockhart, and incidentally it never happens for Malfoy. <br /><br />Rowling allowed the perfect opportunity to make Malfoy a good, three dimensional villain when Harry and Ron used the Polyjuice potion. For the first time, we had Malfoy out of the public eye and in private, where we could see the real him, and not the front everyone else sees. Here was the chance to see his humanity U+2013 that heU+2019s such a prick because heU+2019s afraid of disappointing his father, that he worries about his grades, that thereU+2019s a girl he likes and heU+2019s secretly worried she doesnU+2019t like him back, anything that humanizes him and draws out some sympathy, because thus far heU+2019s gotten nothing more than eye rolls out of me. But we didnU+2019t get that moment. Rowling wrote him no differently than she does when he is on parade in front of everyone, which was really a shame. <br /><br />So, overall, the characters get tiring, but the writing style and imagination are extremely enjoyable. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="18394558106495361038" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div Cruel, sarcastic and disliked by everybody except the students from his own house (Slytherin), Snape taught Potions.<br><br>U+2018Maybe heU+2019s ill!U+2019 said Ron hopefully.<br><br>U+2018Maybe heU+2019s left,U+2018 said Harry, U+2018because he missed out on the Defence Against the Dark Arts job again!U+2019<br><br>U+2018Or he might have been sacked!U+2019 said Ron enthusiastically. U+2018I mean, everyone hates him -U+2018<br><br>U+2018Or maybe,U+2019 said a very cold voice right behind them, U+2018heU+2019s waiting to hear why you two didnU+2019t arrive on the school train.U+2019</i><br><br>What I loved, and still love, about the Harry Potter books wasn't how they gradually became darker and more serious with each book. No, it was the lighthearted, funny subplots that had me hooked to this series. <br>HP and the CoS was full of these happy cutesy scenes, and to this this day it remains my favourite HP book.<br><br>Plus can I just say how much I love the hugging scene at the end of the movie?<br><a href="http://s800.photobucket.com/user/ElleFaye/media/Mobile Uploads/giphy 4_zpsbg3tvfiu.gif.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1466851015ra/19525324.gif" alt=" photo giphy 4_zpsbg3tvfiu.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br><i>U+2018Name U+2026 Harry Potter. Crime U+2026 U+2019<br><br>U+2018It was only a bit of mud!U+2019 said Harry.<br><br>U+2018ItU+2019s only a bit of mud to you, boy, but to me itU+2019s an extra hour scrubbing!U+2019 shouted Filch, a drip shivering unpleasantly at the end of his bulbous nose. U+2018Crime U+2026 befouling the castle U+2026 suggested sentence U+2026 U+2019</i><br><br>Basically, CoS was the last "not too dark" book - unlike the new few novels (in my opinion), it had very magical, fun feel to it.<br><br><i>Harry ducked swiftly down behind his cauldron, pulled one of FredU+2019s Filibuster fireworks out of his pocket and gave it a quick prod with his wand. The firework began to fizz and sputter. Knowing he had only seconds, Harry straightened up, took aim, and lobbed it into the air; it landed right on target in GoyleU+2019s cauldron.<br><br>GoyleU+2019s potion exploded, showering the whole class. People shrieked as splashes of the Swelling Solution hit them.<br><br>U+2018Silence! SILENCE!U+2019 Snape roared. U+2018Anyone who has been splashed, come here for a Deflating Draught. When I find out who did this U+2026 U+2019<br><br>When everyone had taken a swig of antidote and the various swellings had subsided, Snape swept over to GoyleU+2019s cauldron and scooped out the twisted black remains of the firework. There was a sudden hush.<br><br>U+2018If I ever find out who threw this,U+2019 Snape whispered, U+2018I shall make sure that person is expelled.U+2019</i><br><br>I remember reading this part as a child and laughing my head off!<br><br><i>Harry couldnU+2019t believe it - he was free. He wound down the window, the night air whipping his hair, and looked back at the shrinking rooftops of Privet Drive. Uncle Vernon, Aunt Petunia and Dudley were all hanging, dumbstruck, out of HarryU+2019s window.<br><br>U+2018See you next summer!U+2019 Harry yelled.<br><br>The Weasleys roared with laughter and Harry settled back in his seat, grinning from ear to ear.</i><br><br>And of course we can't forget dear Gilderoy Lockhart:<br><br><i>The bell rang and there was a mad rush towards the exit. In the relative calm that followed, Lockhart straightened up, caught sight of Harry, Ron and Hermione, who were almost at the door, and said, U+2018Well, IU+2019ll ask you three to just nip the rest of them back into their cage.U+2019 He swept past them and shut the door quickly behind him.<br><br>U+2018Can you believe him?U+2019 roared Ron, as one of the remaining pixies bit him painfully on the ear.<br><br>U+2018He just wants to give us some hands-on experience,U+2019 said Hermione, immobilising two pixies at once with a clever Freezing Charm and stuffing them back into their cage.<br><br>U+2018Hands on?U+2019 said Harry, who was trying to grab a pixie dancing out of reach with its tongue out. U+2018Hermione, he didnU+2019t have a clue what he was doing.U+2019<br><br>U+2018Rubbish,U+2019 said Hermione. U+2018YouU+2019ve read his books - look at all those amazing things heU+2019s done U+2026 U+2019<br><br>U+2018He says heU+2019s done,U+2019 Ron muttered.</i><br><br>Hehe. You know, I really liked Ron in this book. Can't believe I just said that, because I loathe him in pretty much all the HP books.<br>But he was funny, tolerable and he wasn't being a bitch to Hermione *cough he is in the next book though*.<br><br><i>U+2018Signed photos? YouU+2019re giving out signed photos, Potter?U+2019<br><br>Loud and scathing, Draco MalfoyU+2019s voice echoed around the courtyard. He had stopped right behind Colin, flanked, as he always was at Hogwarts, by his large and thuggish cronies, Crabbe and Goyle.<br><br>U+2018Everyone queue up!U+2019 Malfoy roared to the crowd. U+2018Harry PotterU+2019s giving out signed photos!U+2019</i><br><br><a href="http://s800.photobucket.com/user/ElleFaye/media/Mobile Uploads/giphy 3_zpswgul4tla.gif.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1466849640ra/19525141.gif" alt=" photo giphy 3_zpswgul4tla.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>There wasn't one bit in this book that I skimmed, or skipped. Now that I've read and re-read all the HP books, I tend to skip over parts that I found a bit boring. But CoS? Loved every second of it. <b>5 stars.</b></span>  <a data-text-id="5974009383184807019" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div But re-reading it, I loved it way more than I remembered.<br /><br />This time around, I was really in awe of how well this book is plotted. Maybe it's because I knew what was going to happen, but I noticed just how great all the foreshadowing is. The pacing is much better in this book than in the first book, and I love how the mystery unfolds bit by bit in such a clever way. <br /><br />And maybe it's because the later books are darker in comparison, but I'd almost forgotten how dark this one is, too. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Ginny's involvement with the diary/Tom Riddle/Voldemort is really freaking disturbing if you think about it, especially how Voldemort starts controlling her and making her do horrible things, and she can't even remember it. Like, it honestly makes my stomach hurt and I feel so bad for her. She's so alone and so scared the whole year, and keeping this horrible secretU+2013 U+2013gahh, it's so awful. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />Over all, my re-read of this book was super enjoyable. Great characters, great world-building, and a really fun and clever story. I'm excited to re-read the rest! <br /><br />(Old review (from 2011) under the cut.) <br /><br />----------<br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<br /><b>3/21/11:</b><br /><br />I thought this was quite an improvement from the first book ... mostly because the pacing was very good, unlike the first book which seemed really rushed. This one was also a bit darker. I liked the whole "mystery" aspectU+2013 U+2013even though I read it years ago and I still remembered the ending ... nevertheless, the story unfolds in a very clever way. As usual, the world building is great, etc. I still have some issues with the writing and whatnotU+2013 U+2013but even if the writing isn't the most original style in the world, the story is good. So, I guess that's what matters. I'm interested in getting to the later books to see how this goes ... :)  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span></span>  <a data-text-id="16700624585894807737" href="#" id="reviewTextContainer1696963540" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6484924091211039515">I've heard this is the weakest Harry Potter book, and after having read the first three, I think I agree. Although I feel the first three have been more or less equal in quality.<br /><br />I was annoyed by the new characters (Gilderoy Lockhart, Dobby and Colin Creevey), and I absolutely hate the quidditch scenes and find them excruciatingly boring, something I've complained about to most of the people who tried to convince me to read this.<br /><br />Fortunately, there are two saving graces. One is that the book (and</span>  <span id="freeText6484924091211039515" style="display:none">I've heard this is the weakest Harry Potter book, and after having read the first three, I think I agree. Although I feel the first three have been more or less equal in quality.<br /><br />I was annoyed by the new characters (Gilderoy Lockhart, Dobby and Colin Creevey), and I absolutely hate the quidditch scenes and find them excruciatingly boring, something I've complained about to most of the people who tried to convince me to read this.<br /><br />Fortunately, there are two saving graces. One is that the book (and the series as a whole) is pretty damn exciting, and it's hard to put it down for any reason. The second is the character of Tom Riddle and all the scenes involving him.<br /><br />Since I am reading all the books in direct sequence, the events and characters of each book blend together pretty fast, so I will probably do a more detailed series review at the end.<br /><br />For now, all there is to say is that I am actually enjoying Harry Potter. Who would ever have thought?<br /><br />PS. class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/794900310" />    <a title="Laz" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22313662-laz"><img alt="Laz" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1459126457p2/22313662.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/794900310?book_show_action=false">Jan 21, 2015</a>      <a title="Laz" class="user" name="Laz" href="/user/show/22313662-laz">Laz</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810552" href="/book/show/7979789-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">magic world lovers</span></div>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=classics">classics</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=childrens">childrens</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=sci-fi">sci-fi</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=all-time-favorites">all-time-favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer794900310" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15886563985523881804"><b> <blockquote>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</blockquote> </b><br /><br />While I think the movies are just awesome, I think they fail to capture the magic this book has. This book just enveloped me in my magic. Magic, magic everywhere. Surrounding me. Making me feel like I was a person living inside this magnificent world, but terrifying and dangerous nonetheless.<br /><br />This is the second book in the series and I couldn't have been more satisfied with it, I don't know if there's anything</span>  <span id="freeText15886563985523881804" style="display:none"><b>  <blockquote>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</blockquote></b><br /><br />While I think the movies are just awesome, I think they fail to capture the magic this book has. This book just enveloped me in my magic. Magic, magic everywhere. Surrounding me. Making me feel like I was a person living inside this magnificent world, but terrifying and dangerous nonetheless.<br /><br />This is the second book in the series and I couldn't have been more satisfied with it, I don't know if there's anything bad for me to say about it. I don't know why I'd bother myself trying to figure out what are the flaws of the book and I enjoyed myself so much reading it.<br /><br />I'm not one of those people who try to find every needle in a haystack. I can be satisfied with imperfection, and that's not at all imperfect. It met all of my standards I had set after reading the first book. <br /><br />It was adventurous and the world grows more and more complex, just like I wanted it to be. Learning more about magic, was just as wondrous and exciting as it was for Harry, Hermione and Ron and all those other kids at Hogwarts. I almost feel like I'm a student there, which I wish I were. Take out the Basilisk & Voldemort though because I'd shit my pants. Not that the kids weren't afraid. Of course, they were and that makes it that much more real. The kids have a magnet for trouble. <br /><br />It's so deep, it is a book any kid should be reading instead of reading and obsessing about instead of playing pc games all day and night long. I'll be careful enough to teach my kids how to read and appreciate what books give to us. <br /><br />I love that in the end Harry stands alone and face the enemies without the immediate help of Ron & Hermione. They help him along the way, and that's just as important. <br /><br />It was such a great read and writing this after almost 1 year I feel so drawn to just pick up the book and reread it.</span>  <a data-text-id="15886563985523881804" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review794900310">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link794900310" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=794900310&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_794900310'><a id="like_count_review_794900310" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/794900310?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">34 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_794900310" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_794900310" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=34&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=794900310&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_794900310" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 794900310, true, &#39;&#39;);         >            <span id="freeTextContainer15184507014417569678"><i>Re-Read in December 2015 for Harry Christmas to You</i><br /><br />This time around I realized how much more entertaining this book is compared to the movie. Nothing against the movie because I LOVE it, but this book has so many more fun scenes! Like Arthur and Lucius PHYSICALLY FIGHTING EACH OTHER and Dobby tossing Lucius down a flight of stairs at the end. Reading this aloud with Kyle literally had us laughing like crazy. Nothing against the movie because I LOVE it, but this book has so many more fun scenes! Like Arthur and Lucius PHYSICALLY FIGHTING EACH OTHER and Dobby tossing Lucius down a flight of stairs at the end. Reading this aloud with Kyle literally had us laughing like crazy. I love this series so much oh my Rowling.<br /><br /><i>Re-Read in December 2014 for Harry Christmas to You</i><br /><br />OH MY LORD VOLDEMORT.<br /><br />In this book we get more little hints to events to come in future books (Horcrux stuff, a mention of Voldemort having left a part of himself/his powers in Harry, etc.) WHICH WAS AWESOME. I find that every time I read these books I notice more things, which was definitely true this time around. <br /><br />One thing I did notice, which COULD HAVE SOLVED EVERYTHING:<br /><br />At the beginning of the book when they're leaving for King's Cross, Ginny forgets her diary and has to back for it. SHE NEARLY LEFT IT BEHIND. OH MAN. <br /><br />Overall, this was a great time, but I'm excited to finally get to my favorite books in the series!!!</span>  <a data-text-id="15184507014417569678" href="#" <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/173434838?book_show_action=false">Aug 13, 2011</a>      <a title="Lora" class="user" name="Lora" reviewText">fans of the first</span></div>          <div>    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Lora by: </span>      my enjoyment of the first  </div>          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4632071-lora?shelf=lib-read">lib-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4632071-lora?shelf=middle-grade-lit">middle-grade-lit</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer173434838" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2876589468094320687"><b><i>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities."</i> - Albus Dumbledore</b><br><br>Such a wise wizard.<br><br>You know how sometimes when you read the first in a series and it turns out so much better than you originally anticipated, it makes you a little apprehensive when starting the sequel? Well, I felt that way before starting this, but I can definitely say that <i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is another fabulous installment in the rightfully beloved Harry Potter series!</span>  <span id="freeText2876589468094320687" style="display:none"><b><i>"It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities."</i> - Albus Dumbledore</b><br><br>Such a wise wizard.<br><br>You know how sometimes when you read the first in a series and it turns out so much better than you originally anticipated, it makes you a little apprehensive when starting the sequel? Well, I felt that way before starting this, but I can definitely say that <i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is another fabulous installment in the rightfully beloved Harry Potter series!<br>And while I <i>will</i> admit to not loving it quite as much as its predecessor, I still enjoyed it a great deal. <br>I think the reason for my not liking it as much can be mostly credited to the introduction of a new character, Professor Lockhart. Lockhart is an annoyingly pretentious wizard who is completely full of himself, and the majority of his teachings were based on his own life and his supposed brushes with death that he escaped only because of his "heroism" and great knowledge of the magic arts. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Riiiiiiiiight. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>In a summary, I didn't find the story involving Lockhart quite as interesting as Harry's realization of his true abilities and the escapades of his first year at Hogwarts.<br><br>But HP II undoubtedly still has plenty of hilarious moments and magical wonders - not to mention the lovely cast of characters - to more than compensate for this particular installment's slightly lacking plot. Hence the five stars. :)<br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<img src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/photo.goodreads.com/photos/1308084012p8/284271.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Very clever Ms. Rowling, very clever indeed. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>FAVORITE QUOTE: <i>"I've heard you hate those Muggles you live with," said Ernie swiftly.<br>"It's not possible to live with the Dursleys and not hate them," said Harry. "I'd like to see you try it."</i><br><br>Next up is <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a>, and I'm very much looking forward to it.<br><br>**********************************************************<br><br><b>My reviews of other titles in this series:</b><br><br><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/173429036">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="2876589468094320687" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));;
