liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer981371719" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9857077252930145700">Overall, I loved this, and I can't wait to start <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a> today. <br /><br />Quick thoughts on the things that stood out to me: <br /><br />Wow, the Dursleys were even more loathsome in this book than the first. <br />I love the Weasleys even more than I already did.<br />I am so glad my mother never sent me a Howler.<br />I thought Dobby was annoying in the movie (which I saw when it came out over a decade ago, not having read the book) but I thought he was awesome in the book. In fact, we rewatched the</span>  <span id="freeText9857077252930145700" style="display:none">Overall, I loved this, and I can't wait to start <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a> today. <br /><br />Quick thoughts on the things that stood out to me: <br /><br />Wow, the Dursleys were even more loathsome in this book than the first. <br />I love the Weasleys even more than I already did.<br />I am so glad my mother never sent me a Howler.<br />I thought Dobby was annoying in the movie (which I saw when it came out over a decade ago, not having read the book) but I thought he was awesome in the book. In fact, we rewatched the movie last night, and not only was it as unsatisfying as I remember it, it's just a shit adaptation of this book.<br />I thought it was delightful that <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[the flying car went into the Forbidden Forest and went feral <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>.<br />Tom Riddle's diary was really, really awesome. The entire idea and execution were fantastic.<br /><br />I loved it when Dumbledore told Harry, "It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities." I hope that, as the series goes on, we have more scenes with him, because I really love his wisdom.<br /><br />My minor complaints seem a little nitpicky, and I suppose that if I'm going to suspend disbelief to accept that wizards are real, I should be able to accept that <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[none of the adults at Hogwarts would look in Hermione's fist to see the paper that Harry and Ron found after she was Petrified <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> and <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Fawkes somehow just found his way into the Chamber of Secrets <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, but I'm an adult and if I'd read this as a kid I wouldn't have cared for a single moment.<br /><br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="9857077252930145700" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/381016445?book_show_action=false">Jan 14, 2016</a>      <a title="Evgeny" class="user" name="Evgeny" href="/user/show/9340136-evgeny">Evgeny</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810552" href="/book/show/7979789-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/9340136-evgeny?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer381016445" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11854032305528688404"><b>In memory of Alan Rickman who showed us what Severus Snape looks like on the Big Screen.</b><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1452787089i/17743242.jpg" width="340" height="340" alt="Severus Snape" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>I made myself a promise not to use any stills from any Harry Potter movies in my reviews for any book of the series, but I have to make an exception today January 14, 2016 thus the image above.<br><br>Even people who somehow managed to avoid reading the books and seeing the movies can guess that this book is about Harry Potter's second year the School of Wizardry, Hogwarts. Before he gets there though he had to fight</span>  <span id="freeText11854032305528688404" style="display:none"><b>In memory of Alan Rickman who showed us what Severus Snape looks like on the Big Screen.</b><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1452787089i/17743242.jpg" width="340" height="340" alt="Severus Snape" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>I made myself a promise not to use any stills from any Harry Potter movies in my reviews for any book of the series, but I have to make an exception today January 14, 2016 thus the image above.<br><br>Even people who somehow managed to avoid reading the books and seeing the movies can guess that this book is about Harry Potter's second year the School of Wizardry, Hogwarts. Before he gets there though he had to fight the depression from loneliness as his adopted family does not care about him much and his Hogwarts friends seemingly forgotten about him. <br><br>Fortunately a magical creature called Dobby shows up and instantly makes Harry's life full of excitement: he is convinced Harry's life is forfeit if the latter goes to Hogwarts, so Dobby makes everything in his power to stop Harry from doing this. Injures and maiming are fair game as long as Harry remains alive. To add to the fun it seems Harry's life as well as that of his friends might really be in danger Dobby hinted at. <br><br>Like the first one, this book can still fully qualify as a children book however it is darker and it does have some very gloomy and depressing moments; children grew up and matured a little and so is the tale. <br><br>We get to meet characters familiar from the first book and see their development as well as new interesting ones. Speaking about new people, Gilderoy Lockhart is so full of himself he is excellent. His whole Valentine celebration made me laugh out loud. I think this is the first time we get to meet Lucius Malfoy in person - he is another interesting guy; the last scene with him is excellent. <br><br>I would like to talk about Harry Potter a little. I saw lots of people say he is not the main hero of the series; he is just a guy who always gets either lucky, or have a helpful friend handy in tight spots. I saw Hermione named the main hero - she is the brainpower behind Harry's successes most of the time. I saw Neville named the main hero - he has the greatest and most unexpected development of all characters. I would respectfully disagree: Harry Potter is the main hero albeit a reluctant one (compare him to Lockhart to see why). For the proof of this look no further than the final confrontation in this novel. <br><br>This was my reread of the book; I knew exactly what to expect and I was sure I would rate it with 4 stars until I found myself awoke well in the early morning hours finishing this reread despite the fact that I had to wake up early. Any book which can do it to me deserves 5 stars. <br><br>I do not have anything else to add to what I already said; each installment of the series was analyzed and reviewed countless number of times by better qualified people. I will stop right here.</span>  <a data-text-id="11854032305528688404" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review381016445">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link381016445" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=381016445&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_381016445'><a id="like_count_review_381016445" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/381016445?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">128 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_381016445" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_381016445" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=128&rating[page]=1&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=381016445&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_381016445" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 381016445, true, &#39;&#39;); The Black Company is the father of all grimdar</span>  <span id="freeText13899307329003834413" style="display:none"><i>Ivana wrote: "I shall take that as a book recommendation:)"</i><br /><br />Let me give you at least a glimpse of these. The Black Company is the father of all grimdark fantasy. There are no good guys, but some people grow on you. The writing is minimalist (it is annals of the company of mercenaries and as such there are almost no description of cloths, food, nature, etc.) If you get past this this is really engaging read. <br /><br /><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/30005.Red_Harvest" title="Red Harvest by Dashiell Hammett">Red Harvest</a> is one of the classics of noir. It most probably has the highest number of dead bodies per book, but does not feel macabre. <br /><br />If you like these genres by all means take a look at these.</span>  <a class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3117330459004247436"><blockquote> <i>It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.</i> </blockquote><br /><br />Little did I know that I would instantly fall in love with this world and already miss it when I would finish it. Oh little did I know about the happiness I feel when I read about Harry and his friends and little am I expecting what is coming up.<br /><br /><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> stars off where <i>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</i> left off. Harry goes back to his old home for summer and spends time with h</span>  <span id="freeText3117330459004247436" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <i>U+275DIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+275E</i></blockquote><br /><br />Little did I know that I would instantly fall in love with this world and already miss it when I would finish it. Oh little did I know about the happiness I feel when I read about Harry and his friends and little am I expecting what is coming up.<br /><br /><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> stars off where <i>Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</i> left off. Harry goes back to his old home for summer and spends time with his ugly family, The Dursleys. They are no different then they were before but in fact are even more rude. As Harry thinks about going back to Hogwarts, a new and ugly creature appears in Harry's bedroom as Harry returns upstairs. His name is Dobby and he is known as a house-elf, one that is treated badly. But Dobby didn't come to chat with Harry, he came to warn him. Warn him about Hogwarts and <i>save him</i>, telling him he must not return to Hogwarts. He says this because he is trying to warn Harry and tell him that he can put the whole school in danger including his friends and himself. But because Harry does not listen and is actually able to go back to Hogwarts thanks to his best friend Ron, a lot of things happen this second year and some aren't the best. Some include agony being made and being taken back in time, a new professor named Gilderon Lockheart, a spirit/ghost who died in Hogwarts and now haunts the girls bathroom named Moaning Myrtle, and even events having to do with Ron Weasley's younger sister, Ginny. These aren't the only events happening and the only ones making Hogwarts suffer. They actually have nothing to do with it. There is somethingU+2014or maybe someoneU+2014who is leading Hogwarts to danger and putting everyone at risk. This person, or thing, is turning students into stone, writing on the walls, and killing a professor's cat. As rumors spread, nobody knows who this might be. It might be Draco Malfoy, since he is known as an evil child wizard in Slytherin, or maybe Hagrid, since he has been in Hogwarts for a very long time, including his studying years there. Or any other professor, including Snape, Dumbledore, McGonagall, or even Lockhart. But if it isn't any of those, then it might just be Harry himself.<br /><br />I really don't know what to say. Words aren't possible because this book was just so wonderful and so fun. There were even more magical journeys and I was so glad everyone has changes and J.K. Rowling decided to changer everyone's character. Well, almost. Where do I start? Harry is still the cute cinnamon roll and I love his precious and cute character. I hate how he had to suffer even more with the Dursley's and had to even go back as the second year ended. I hope he escapes one day for good and never returns because I am so tired of him being treated like shit and like he really does not exist. His family is the only family he really has, yet they treat him like they wish he was dead and didn't survive The Chamber of Secrets. Sure, that's what they wish, but they should show a little more empathy with him and treat him a little better, maybe feed him more food and give him better clothes, let him go out with his owl and have some freedom, let him write back to his friends when they know he is miserable with them, and just be the young Harry Potter he was made to be. Other than that, he is growing and growing into a much better wizard and is slowly learning even more spells, which he ended up using some to defend his friend and fight Draco with.<br /><br />Ron, oh Ron he is so cute and precious but so dumb in such cute ways. He still can't figure out the right magic spells and how to use them, making the rest of the crowd laugh at him because of his silly actions. He's so funny and when he's worried, his face reactions are so cute but so heartbreaking at times because he is just so adorable. Draco didn't mock him like he did in the previous book and I was glad for that but he still received laughter from others because of the message he got from his mother, the way he tried learning transfiguration, and for needing his mother to defend him. He isn't learning quick like Harry but I know the time will come and he will become a good wizard and be able to change things into the right objects, be able to drive a flying car correctly, and defend his friend like he defended him when he needed the saving. <br /><br />Hermione was probably my favorite. She has changed so much and isn't a bossy high-top nerd anymore. She's always at the top, able to answer questions before anyone and earning Gryffindor points, and that is the reason I loved her a lot more. What would Gryffindor, Harry, and Ron do without Hermione? Like my friends have said, probably dead or lost because they can't figure out what to do or how things work. She actually breaks rules in this book to help Harry and Ron and is also helping them with the secrets they are trying to discover. She still supports Harry with his Quidditch matches and is there for them when they need help, even when she wasn't supposed to.<br /><br />You might be wondering what the 4 stars mean? Well, like others, Ginny was my least favorite character. I wish she didn't get in the way and wasn't the reason for the secrets, but she was also really dumb. She acted dumb in front of Harry and tried stepping up for him, only embarrassing herself. She was embarrassed by her mom because she was accepted into Gryffindor, but she was still dumb. She didn't have to listen to Riddle and could've made the choice of leaving everything out. Of course, the book would be different and maybe quite boring if it wasn't for her, but I still didn't like her character majority of the time. I hear she's one of the least favorite characters and I can see why. She's pretty annoying and is always blushing when she sees Harry. I'm guessing she likes him? Dobby was not my favorite either, only because he tried telling Harry what to do but at the end, sure, I liked him and was glad he was free because Malfoy was not a good master for him. He kicked and hit him for no reasons, so I'm sure that the reason for his actions when Harry told him to sit.<br /><br />The friendship has definetely grown and Hermione, Ron and Harry are just best friends. They worry about each and everything about them together is just so cute. I will admit that I liked this one a little less than the first one, but just a little bit. I don't use half stars or anything anymore, so don't be thinking the first one was better and this one had its flaws because it really didn't disappoint me. I just hated some characters and that happens in all novels, and Draco is still one of them. He's an asshole, fight me! Like him or not, I feel like I will always hate him. I feel like he will grow out to be just like this father and become an evil wizard like all Slytherins do. I know his appearance won't change and his personality won't either. He treats Harry like shit as well because of who he is and sometimes he thinks he's cool because of his father. But his father is nothing but a lousy and loud man that tries to show off because of his son and because of what he can afford. There was nothing new about him and I hate him for almost everything. Well, everything actually.<br /><br />Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets did not disappoint and left me upset, but it had different flaws than the first one. Bad ones, but I'm sure they'll be fixed sometimes. I just didn't like Dobby at the beginning, but like I said, I was glad he was free at the end and defended Harry from Lucius Malfoy. I know every story has its own improvement and all analyze, but this one might be my least favorite. It's like I see it coming. Overall, I can't wait to see where the next journey takes off and how Harry will escape the Dursley's again.</span>  <a data-text-id="3117330459004247436" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/14146681" />    <a title="Chris" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/858949-chris"><img alt="Chris" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1208350750p2/858949.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/14146681?book_show_action=false">Feb 09, 2008</a>      <a title="Chris" class="user" name="Chris" href="/user/show/858949-chris">Chris</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780439064873" href="/book/show/50968.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/858949-chris?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/858949-chris?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer14146681" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13170395281850567504"><i>Since pretty much everyone I know has read these books, I figure reviewing them is pretty pointless. But with the new book coming out in a couple of weeks, I have to go through them beginning to end. To make the reviews more entertaining, I will be doing them in a variety of unexpected formats. For this review, I will be writing as someone who's just getting into Freudian theory.</i><br /><br />From the very beginning, the true nature of this story is quite obvious - The Chamber of Secrets. There is only one "c</span>  <span id="freeText13170395281850567504" style="display:none"><i>Since pretty much everyone I know has read these books, I figure reviewing them is pretty pointless. But with the new book coming out in a couple of weeks, I have to go through them beginning to end. To make the reviews more entertaining, I will be doing them in a variety of unexpected formats. For this review, I will be writing as someone who's just getting into Freudian theory.</i><br /><br />From the very beginning, the true nature of this story is quite obvious - The Chamber of Secrets. There is only one "chamber of secrets" that is of any human concern, and it is no coincidence that the book of such a title was written by a woman.<br /><br />By sending her young, immature male character, Harry (whose name, along with Tom and Dick, just happens to be one of the "universal" male names) into the mysterious Chamber, Rowling is exploring her memories of early childhood sexuality. The Chamber is filled not only with mystery, but danger and legend - its very existence is debated, which no doubt refers to the elusive female orgasm.<br /><br />Ms. Rowling, whose sexual impulses have no doubt been unfulfilled over the years, is attempting to fulfill them by way of her own fiction. She has created a perfect sexual explorer in Harry Potter - a young, innocent and noble young man whose powers have not yet matured. Obviously a male that Rowling would feel comfortable with. This is especially interesting given the actual resident of the Chamber of Secrets - a huge, deadly serpent. And there's only one thing that a huge, terrible serpent can represent.<br /><br />Rowling's sexual past is the fertile ground in which this book was grown. It is her cathartic attempt to win over the guilty feelings that she's repressed from her former sexual life, the one she regrets more than anything else, by manufacturing a hero. That hero, in Harry Potter, represents the type of man for whom she would "open" her "chamber - pure of heart and noble of intention and, most importantly, under her control. The vanquishing of the serpent-symbol is her victory, leaving her free to explore other aspects of her life, including the eventual resolution of the Electra complex that appears to have been built up around Professor Dumbledore...</span>  <a data-text-id="13170395281850567504" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div But I really couldn't help it! THIS BOOK WAS SO GOOD AND I COULD NOT STOP READING IT!!<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1464350135ra/19229896.gif" width="280" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>okay now let's talking about this book! <br><br><b>  <u>My Opinion</u></b><br><br>omg! this book! I had a lot of feelings! Anger. Sadness. Happiness and many more and the chapter I most loved was The Duelling Club. it was so funny to see Professor Snape disarmed Lockhart until he was flying because of the impact of Professor Snape's spell hahaha. xD<br>I don't like calling Lockhart a Professor because he clearly didn't know any spells that were usefull for his students or anyone... Maybe just a Memory Charm. but it was only usefull for him to do his nasty business. ugh and he was a liar too. all those books he wrote were all faked. <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1472908645ra/20352007.gif" width="270" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>If Hogwarts were real, I would be really happy to learn all about Defence Against The Dark Arts. this is the most interesting subject that have really caught my interest since I began reading the first book. what about you guys? tell me on the comment section below! ^^<br>and that Duelling Club was so amazing! learning how to fight with spells! <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1412532195ra/11387341.gif" width="270" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471536608ra/20069350.gif" width="270" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>and what schocked me was that Voldemort was used to be a human! and Voldemort was not his real name. His real name was Tom Marvolo Riddle but he changed it. <br>I mean, not an ordinary human,of course. he was a muggle-born. his father was a muggle and his mother was a witch. I knew he was a Slytherin and he studied at Hogwarts too but I never thought him as muggle-born or a child or a teenager. because he was so evil that I couldn't even imagine what he would look like in the past and he *coughs coughs * used to be handsome...<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1472911775ra/20353398.gif" width="260" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>oh! I love Quidditch too! I don't really like sports but it's different with Quidditch. Quidditch is wonderful and amazing! I even always scream like " YOU CAN DO IT HARRY! YOU CAN CATCH IT!" and when Gryffindor wins I always scream like " YAY!! GRYFFINDOR! GRYFFINDOR! " Am I weird? hahaaha. <br>AHHH. I wish Hogwarts were real. I wish I were at least a muggle-born. I have only read two books in Harry Potter series but they already have changed my life. <br><br>thank you guys for reading and liking this review! I hope you guys have a great day and Happy Reading!! pretending I'm not there.U+201D </b> </blockquote> <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456411329i/18231665._SY540_.jpg" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Re-read - </b>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the twin of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. This book is not so far from the first one and I love how joyful it is. Harry Potter comes back to his family, if I can call them that. For this summer, Dobby prevents Harry from going back to Hogwart. He says something will happen and it means death for Harry Potter and everyone.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1456411329ra/18231666.gif" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>J.K. Rowling never lets us down with her</span>  <span id="freeText7430514891499217161" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <b>U+201CI'll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I'm not there.U+201D </b></blockquote> <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456411329i/18231665._SY540_.jpg" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Re-read - </b>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the twin of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. This book is not so far from the first one and I love how joyful it is. Harry Potter comes back to his family, if I can call them that. For this summer, Dobby prevents Harry from going back to Hogwart. He says something will happen and it means death for Harry Potter and everyone.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1456411329ra/18231666.gif" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>J.K. Rowling never lets us down with her second installment of Harry Potter. The book itself flows smoothly without dropping. Harry, Ron and Hermione are the lead characters that I love most. They try to carry out their plans about the clue that left behind. I enjoyed watching the way they solve the problem and while they're conducting something, Ron is the one that always made me laugh out loud. Hermione is the brain of this group, though, she's smart and subtle. And Harry is the brave one, although he is so scared about the whispers, he drives into the pipe without hesitation in the end. I really adored him !<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1382355842ra/5843750.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>This book is entertaining for many reasons. Lockhart is a colorful character, without him, this book will not be complete. The only thing I want to say about this series is it gets better and better. When you pick the book up, you can't put it down for hours. Harry Potter is my addiction and life. That's all !!<br><br><blockquote>  <b>U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D</b></blockquote> <br><br>And for the Dark lord, this book isn't your time to slay. id="freeTextContainer3394643111453593392"><i>U+201CI'll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I'm not there.U+201D</i><br />-Me, reading Harry Potter<br /><br />To say it with the words of my 7 year old brother: "It was good but badder than the first book."<br /><br />This is Harry Potter. Nothing can ever beat a Harry Potter book. Apart from another Harry Potter book. And in this 7 (and a half) part series, this is my least favourite book. There's just so many things I don't like reading about. Harry and Ron stealing the car and flying it to Hogwart? Gilderoy Lockhart? N</span>  <span id="freeText3394643111453593392" style="display:none"><i>U+201CI'll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I'm not there.U+201D</i><br />-Me, reading Harry Potter<br /><br />To say it with the words of my 7 year old brother: "It was good but badder than the first book."<br /><br />This is Harry Potter. Nothing can ever beat a Harry Potter book. Apart from another Harry Potter book. And in this 7 (and a half) part series, this is my least favourite book. There's just so many things I don't like reading about. Harry and Ron stealing the car and flying it to Hogwart? Gilderoy Lockhart? Nah, I could happily go without it.<br />But then there's things that are just brilliant. The Valentines dwarf singing Harry a love song! Hermione Granger being a genius through and through! Fawkes! Unwillingly funny Moaning Myrtle!<br /><br />I think one of the reasons this may be the weakest part of the series is, that it resembles Part One so much: Someone tries to hurt Harry during Quidditch, there's a hidden chamber deep underneath Hogwarts and Harry has to face Voldemort in said chamber.<br /><br />Now, you have to understand that there is nothing I love more than Harry Potter, and this book is one of the most brilliant things ever written. I'm a proud Potterhead and Gryffindor and will forever love this world. a few other Potter heads at <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/group/show/148164-buddies-books-and-baubles">Buddies Books and Baubles</a>. Let the magic commence. <br /><br /><b>Me:</b> Harry Potter Reread! YAY *squee*<br /><br /><b>Hubs:</b> Seriously, you are rereading them. Haven't you read them already and watched all the movies.<br /><br /><b>Me:</b> Yes....but I like to reread them every few years. Let the magic commence. <br /><br /><b>Me:</b> Harry Potter Reread! YAY *squee*<br /><br /><b>Hubs:</b> Seriously, you are rereading them. Haven't you read them already and watched all the movies.<br /><br /><b>Me:</b> Yes....but I like to reread them every few years. They are magical like that and I want to jump back into that whole world again.<br /><br /><b>Hubs:</b> *Blank Stare* but you already know what happens.<br /><br /><b>Me:</b> That doesn't mean anything. Well it does, it means that I now have time to over-analyze the whole thing and catch little things I missed the first few times. That is the best thing about rereading the HP books.<br /><br /><b>Hubs:</b> I don't understand....you could just watch the movies it would take less time.<br /><br /><b>Me:</b> *blank stare* How did we ever end up together? The book is always better than the movie. Except Stardust and The Princess Bride those I liked the movies more.<br /><br /><b>Hubs:</b> Inconceivable.<br /><br /><b>Me:</b> There 'that' is how we ended up together.<br /><br />Still it is amazing to me to reread these with a group of people and relive all the little things I'd forgotten along the way. I love growing up with Harry, Hermione and Ron all over again and going through all those trying times that solidify them as a great trio of friends.<br /><br />Chamber of Secrets is so well done and I absolutely loved having the why would they ever hire Lockheart as a professor. Well....I now know definitively why according to JKR but we had some fun ideas too.<br /><br />For a children's book I can't stress how well thought out all these are and the magical feeling I get when reading one. I'm almost always sad to realize that I'm probably a muggle *gasps* or a squib but either way I don't care I'll always try on occasion to cast a spell...because yes I have a wand and I'm convinced that one day it will work so I just have to keep trying.<br /><br />*wyngardium leviosa*</span>  <a data-text-id="9760621198664698592" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1503886113">  <td id="review_1733851119" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1733851119" />    <a title="Luke Taylor" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30710594-luke-taylor"><img alt="Luke Taylor" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1476826671p2/30710594.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1733851119?book_show_action=false">Aug 24, 2016</a>      <a title="Luke Taylor" class="user" name="Luke Taylor" href="/user/show/30710594-luke-taylor">Luke Taylor</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408855904" href="/book/show/22037377-harry-potter-and-the-chamber-of-secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=hall-of-fame">hall-of-fame</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=i-own-a-copy">i-own-a-copy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=special-hardcover">special-hardcover</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=magic">magic</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1733851119" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7185363169302966722">So, what is Harry Potter and The Chamber of Secrets?<br /><br />Why perhaps one of the greatest sequels ever written?<br /><br />Ha! Then why is it the lowest rated of the 7? Why do so many consider it to be their least favorite?<br /><br />I don't know! I thought it was flipping amazing.<br /><br />Why?<br /><br />Because Jo Rowling, so very English and erudite, with her topsy turvy hilarious and creepy narrative, her human characters and her timeless topics; Jo, who knows the human heart like Hermione knows the works of Gilderoy Lockhart, hides the mot</span>  <span id="freeText7185363169302966722" style="display:none">So, what is Harry Potter and The Chamber of Secrets?<br /><br />Why perhaps one of the greatest sequels ever written?<br /><br />Ha! Then why is it the lowest rated of the 7? Why do so many consider it to be their least favorite?<br /><br />I don't know! I thought it was flipping amazing.<br /><br />Why?<br /><br />Because Jo Rowling, so very English and erudite, with her topsy turvy hilarious and creepy narrative, her human characters and her timeless topics; Jo, who knows the human heart like Hermione knows the works of Gilderoy Lockhart, hides the motives of every character till the perfect moment of revelation. Even those that should be above suspicion are not with the taint of pride and ambition, and even the most beloved characters breathe with the fragility of humanity as the story relentlessly runs along through the darkened halls of Hogwarts. <br /><br />Beware, second-year students, the desire to be great is a double-edged sword beset with rubies.<br /><br />I first became a fan of Jo with Cuckoo's Calling and it occurred to me, breathlessly reading through Chamber of Secrets, that the Riddle was solved. Finally. Why is Jo Rowling so good? It's simple. <br /><br />She's a mystery writer.<br /><br />Harry Potter soars above Muggle mystery books because of its special additives. Magic, yes, and undeniably malleable lenient fantasy elements that Jo masterfully weaves and waves her wand over to manipulate and beef up the story as she sees fit, but truly, how many mysteries have we read (collectively) where we set them down and forget who the detective was, or the suspect, or whatever. Why is that? Because of Jo's reverse engineering (no doubt an ancient Slytherin technique) where the character comes first. No matter what, and no matter which character. The books are entirely character driven and because we love The Boy Who Lived and He Who Shall Not Be Named and The Weasleys and Rubeus Hagrid and Ginny (the cutest human being on planet earth) and on and on and on, we find ourselves shoulder to shoulder with our would-be sleuths and puzzle solvers and their "we must we must" attitude. Chamber of Secrets was an outstanding mystery, chock-full of red herrings, an incredible combative climax, and too many laugh-out-loud lines to count. <br /><br />Dear Diary, I have a new favorite book.<br /><br />Oh really, what is it?<br /><br />*Throws diary out the window and runs away screaming*<br /><br />And, shivers, at the mere mention of Azkaban, I read Chamber of Secrets with far too much excitement and anticipation, because, knowing I was going into Harry Potter, The Prisoner of Azkaban, following Chamber of Secrets, was the book I was waiting for the most, and for that I blame Gary Oldman. (I am a Sirius fan of Gary Oldman) That said, I had no idea that Chamber of Secrets would be so outstanding and leave me thinking the incredible Philosopher's Stone was a perfectly-pitched welcome handshake compared to the books to come.<br /><br />For those who like to feel up a book for flaws, I have none, and I see none. I see the sheer verve of adventure and the scintillating luster of mystery, gleaming hungry-eyed and ready for more. You see, as Philosopher's Stone was about love, Chamber of Secrets was about fearlessness. Fearlessness to speak the truth in the face of a lie, fearlessness to stand up for what's inside your heart. Fearlessness to take a leap of faith and follow the path of destiny.<br /><br />Also, I am very interested in how the issues gain maturity as Harry and the other characters age. Obviously there are deaths to come, but in the case of Chamber of Secrets versus Philosopher's Stone, I could feel that sense of maturity creeping in just a bit, and am so very excited for the continuation of the series (I'll have to go buy some more chocolate frogs now) as everything in the Wizarding World becomes increasingly dangerous and unhinged and wild and wondrously unforgettable.<br /><br />Recommended for everyone.<br /><br />And 50 points for Hermione for being epic even whilst being petrified.</span>  <a data-text-id="7185363169302966722" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4110504303076779785">The Harry Potter series is like one giant puzzle, and during every book, tiny puzzle pieces start fitting together and forming a whole. There are hints everywhere about what's going to happen, sort of like inside jokes for people who've already read the books, but the mystery remains. J.K. Rowling keeps you guessing up until the final pages.<br><br>I love how every character brings something else to the table. Ron's dry comments, Fred and George's pranks, Hermione's cleverness, Dumbledore's charming str</span>  <span id="freeText4110504303076779785" style="display:none">The Harry Potter series is like one giant puzzle, and during every book, tiny puzzle pieces start fitting together and forming a whole. There are hints everywhere about what's going to happen, sort of like inside jokes for people who've already read the books, but the mystery remains. J.K. Rowling keeps you guessing up until the final pages.<br><br>I love how every character brings something else to the table. Ron's dry comments, Fred and George's pranks, Hermione's cleverness, Dumbledore's charming strangeness. Even side characters like Mr and Mrs Weasley have such a strong individuality. They're all fleshed out.<br><br><i>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</i> is an exciting, thrilling read. It makes you think along with the Golden Trio and laugh out loud. It makes you cheer characters on and boo others. You're engaged for the entire story and there's no way out. You can't escape. Hogwarts is your home.<br><br><a href="http://tinypic.com?ref=2rd9mow" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1380358778ra/709934.gif" alt="Image and video hosting by TinyPic" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a></span>  <a data-text-id="4110504303076779785" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/83629671" />    <a title="Elisa " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3112505-elisa"><img alt="Elisa " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1452314605p2/3112505.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/83629671?book_show_action=false">Mar 15, 2014</a>      <a title="Elisa " class="user" name="Elisa " href="/user/show/3112505-elisa">Elisa </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3112505-elisa?shelf=kids-fiction">kids-fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3112505-elisa?shelf=seven-greatest-books-ever">seven-greatest-books-ever</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer83629671" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2903015489403079439">A lot of people cite this book as their least favorite in the Potter saga; many of my friends included. When I asked one of my friends why he felt it was the worst of the bunch, he gave me a very reasonable reply. He'd come in late on the Potter game, having only read them last year in fact, when a Professor of his was walking them through what it takes to be a good mystery-- using <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a> as an example of a perfectly fashioned mystery.<br /><br />Moving on to the second book,</span>  <span id="freeText2903015489403079439" style="display:none">A lot of people cite this book as their least favorite in the Potter saga; many of my friends included. When I asked one of my friends why he felt it was the worst of the bunch, he gave me a very reasonable reply. He'd come in late on the Potter game, having only read them last year in fact, when a Professor of his was walking them through what it takes to be a good mystery-- using <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a> as an example of a perfectly fashioned mystery.<br /><br />Moving on to the second book, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a>, my friend (let's call him Rex) found that this book wasn't up to standard mystery-wise in the way the first book had been, which is what he'd been expecting. Maybe it's because I first read it as a child, or it's maybe because I was more interested in the fantasy aspect, but I never really cared, nor do I care now that it doesn't follow the same standard mystery guidelines. <br /><br />Rex was the only person who gave me an answer other than "I don't know, I just don't like it as much," so therefore his is the only one that I'm able to analyze. But enough negativity, allow me to explain what I <i>do</i> like about it.<br /><br />Um, Ron's broken wand? Hysterical. Well, if I'm being honest, any single scene including Mr. Ron Weasley is bound to make me smile and any interaction between him and Hermione (yes, even this early on) is bound to make me squee!!!!!!!!!! Notice how quick he is to jump to Hermione's defense; notice how distraught he is over Hermione's being petrified. Oh, how I love them.<br /><br />To add a few more- Harry's first trip to the Burrow! The flying car! Fred and George marching ahead of Harry, announcing him mockingly as the Heir of Slytherin! The singing Valentine's Day Dwarves! And our introduction to the Whomping Willow! Come on people, this is classic stuff!<br /><br />I also love the part Ginny Weasley plays in this book; not so much the whole "helping the Heir of Slytherin thing," but her mad crush on Harry. Maybe because I was granted the fortune/misfortune of having a brother a grade above me, I also had the wonderful fortune/misfortune of crushing on all his super hott (yes with two t's) friends. Ah, how I remember the days of pining for them, of whining over their lack of return interest, of cursing my blasted gapped teeth and frizzy hair. Of course, unlike Ginny I was never able to woo any of them in the end, (even after my braces!) but I still think I did alright as far as men go;)<br /><br />Okay, back to the text. I even enjoy ol' Lockhart, for what he's worth. Yeah, he's obnoxious, but that's the point, right? And yeah, the degree to whch he is obnoxious is a little cartoony and unrealistic, but let's not forget- this is a children's book, after all. <br /><br />Chamber of Secrets also sees Harry destroying his first Horcrux, and offers us our first insight into one Tom Riddle. I would never discount this book, or cast it so carelessly aside as least favorite of the bunch (I don't believe in ranking these books, by the way). Anyway, it receives a full five stars from me with zero hesitation. I appreciate it's contribution to the Potter world and will look forward to reading it again when the time comes...which it will.<br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="2903015489403079439" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review83629671">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link83629671" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=83629671&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_83629671'><a id="like_count_review_83629671" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/83629671?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">67 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_83629671" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_83629671" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=67&rating[page]=1&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=83629671&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_83629671" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 83629671, true, &#39;&#39;);       <span id="reviewTextContainer241902773" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1421168155570739169"><br>About a year ago I <s>threw a tantrum</s> begged Delee to read Harry Potter with me. She had never read it and I just simply canU+2019t accept that. Because letU+2019s face it:<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1433273395i/15075416._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg">.<br><br>Well, she inevitably, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/900860104"> jumped on the bandwagon</a> with the rest of the world. I was so thrilled that she not only finally read it but that she loved it. It took her a whole year to get around to the next book, but she did and thatU+2019s all that matters. SheU+2019s already given this one <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1268939794?book_show_action=false"> 5 stars</a>! AND weU+2019ve scheduled our reading of Prisoner of Azkaba</span>  <span id="freeText1421168155570739169" style="display:none"><br>About a year ago I <s>threw a tantrum</s> begged Delee to read Harry Potter with me. She had never read it and I just simply canU+2019t accept that. Because letU+2019s face it:<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1433273395i/15075416._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg">.<br><br>Well, she inevitably, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/900860104"> jumped on the bandwagon</a> with the rest of the world. I was so thrilled that she not only finally read it but that she loved it. It took her a whole year to get around to the next book, but she did and thatU+2019s all that matters. SheU+2019s already given this one <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1268939794?book_show_action=false"> 5 stars</a>! AND weU+2019ve scheduled our reading of Prisoner of Azkaban for August** of this year. IU+2019m one excited Potthead!<br><br>Chamber of Secrets catches some heat from fans for being too much like the first one. But, I assure you itU+2019s really not <i>that</i> similar. Sure, thereU+2019s our favorite trio once again keeping secrets from adults who could totally use that information. Sure, thereU+2019s something sinister going on in the school causing everyoneU+2019s feathers to be ruffled. Sure, thereU+2019s a Professor who isnU+2019t exactly who he says he is.<br><br>But, this story is different. And damn it, it is FUN. I canU+2019t tell you, now, how many times I have reread this series. What I <b>can </b> tell you is that every single time this one gets funnier and funnier. There was more than one occasion where my giggling fits caused the bed to shake leading to JerridU+2019s disgruntled complaints. His grumblings went unnoticed though, for how am I to show any self-control whenever Professor Lockhart is in the room? <br><br>JK RowlingU+2019s books are something truly special, something that will live within us for the rest of our lives. The quotes from these books are as engrained in our brains as our own names. I look forward to continuing this journey with Delee. I can only hope that there will be others that will follow her lead and give these books a chance when they thought them not worth their time. Trust me on this, if youU+2019re not reading these books youU+2019re making a huge mistake. <br><br>Just remember what Dumbledore says:<br><b> U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D </b><br><br>YouU+2019re my next <s>victim</s> prospect, Jeff. Best be ready, MahFah.<br><br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="1421168155570739169" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review241902773">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link241902773" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=241902773&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_241902773'><a id="like_count_review_241902773" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/241902773?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">62 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_241902773" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_241902773" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=62&rating[page]=1&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=241902773&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_241902773" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 241902773, true, &#39;&#39;); class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781551922447" href="/book/show/480478.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a           <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=childrens-fantasy">childrens-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=ya-lit">ya-lit</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=tween-time">tween-time</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=books-i-love">books-i-love</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=pottermania">pottermania</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=epic-fantasy">epic-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/114559-namratha?shelf=children-s">children-s</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer4148875" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1410739560974773129">In a bid to recapture the Harry Potteresque brand of nostalgia, I am re-reading the series. And loving every bit of it. <br /><br />I always find that the second offering in a long-running series is always the most fulfilling. After the first book, we have the character profiles down to a tee, we have decided on our personal favourites and pet-peeves and we can easily summon up the scenery and the ambience. So now itU+2019s just a question of belting-up and getting ready for more nail-biting action.<br />And <b> <u>Harry Po</u></b></span>  <span id="freeText1410739560974773129" style="display:none">In a bid to recapture the Harry Potteresque brand of nostalgia, I am re-reading the series. And loving every bit of it. <br /><br />I always find that the second offering in a long-running series is always the most fulfilling. After the first book, we have the character profiles down to a tee, we have decided on our personal favourites and pet-peeves and we can easily summon up the scenery and the ambience. So now itU+2019s just a question of belting-up and getting ready for more nail-biting action.<br />And <b>  <u>Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</u></b> does just that. <br /><br /><b>Harry</b> knows whoU+2019s baying for his blood (<i><b>Malfoy</b>, <b>Snape</b> and good olU+2019Mouldy-<b>Voldy</b></i>) He has a clearer picture of his own powers and abilities. I wonU+2019t mention the plot as most of us already know it by rote and those who donU+2019t, are getting converted...as I speak.<br /><br />The high point of the second book is a mysterious...erm....MYSTERY. Rather than laboring on about HarryU+2019s traumatized past and his future trials, it deals with his actual adventures in the present day. Mysterious mumblings in the walls, an unknown beast lurking in some obscure chamber and hapless victims, this book has all the makings of a classic detective novel. Harry Potter gets a chance to prove that all the adulation and hero-worship is justified and he puts up a knock-U+2018em dead, magnificent fight. <b>Rowling</b> manages to weave in her wise homilies towards the end <blockquote>  <i>    <b>(U+201CIt is our choices, Harry, that show us what we truly are, far more than our abilities.U+201D )</b>  </i></blockquote> and yet again, it fits perfectly. Not preachy, not patronizing but tailor-made to clear HarryU+2019s misgivings.<br /><br />A rich, satisfying read.</span>  <a data-text-id="1410739560974773129" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"
